revision.text:
The '''1st Infantry Division''' is a military formation of the [[Korean People's Army]].
It was part of the North Korean advance from [[Seoul]] to [[Taejon]].
The division fought in the [[Battle of Pusan Perimeter]].<ref>{{cite book | url = http://www.history.army.mil/brochures/KW-Outbreak/outbreak.htm | title = The Korean War: The Outbreak| publisher = [[United States Army Center of Military History]]| first = William J.| last =Webb| id = CMH Pub 19-6 }}</ref>
The intelligence section of [[Far East Command (United States)|U.S Far East Command]] headquarters listed the divisions order of battle as a 31 July 1952 as follows:<ref>{{cite book|title=History of the North Korean Army|date=31 July 1952|publisher=Headquarters, Far East Command. Intelligence Section|pages=141}}</ref> *2nd Regiment *3rd Regiment *14th Regiment *Artillery Regiment
This same report listed the 1st Division as being in III Corps Reserve at the same time period.<ref>{{cite book|title=History of the North Korean Army|date=31 July 1952|publisher=Headquarters, Far East Command. Intelligence Section|pages=75}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Military units and formations of North Korea in the Korean War|InfDiv0001]] [[Category:Infantry divisions of North Korea|InfDiv0001NK]]

revision.text:
{{more citations needed|date=April 2014}} {{Infobox automobile | name = Antarctic Snow Cruiser | image = Snow cruiser 2.jpg | caption = The Antarctic Snow Cruiser, as it was abandoned (December 22, 1940) | manufacturer = [[Armour Institute of Technology]] | aka = The Penguin, Penguin 1, Turtle | production = 1937-1939 | model_years = 1939 | assembly = United States: [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]] | factory = [[Pullman Company]] | designer = [[Thomas Poulter]] | class = Class 9 | body_style = | layout = [[Front-engine, four-wheel-drive layout|Longitudinal front-engine, four-wheel drive]] | platform = | related = | engine = Two {{convert|672|cuin|L|1|abbr=on|disp=flip}} [[Cummins]] H-6 diesel engines |powerout = {{convert|112|kW|PS|abbr=on|0|}} each |motor = Four 56kW electric motors | transmission = | propulsion = | wheelbase = {{convert|NNN|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} | length = {{convert|669|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} | width = {{convert|239|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} | height = Wheels extended: {{convert|192|in|mm|0|abbr=on}}
Wheels retracted: {{convert|144|in|mm|0|abbr=on|}} | weight = {{convert|75,000|lb|kg|0|abbr=on}} | predecessor = | successor = | sp = us }} [[File:Snow cruiser 1.jpg|285px|right|thumb|Radio operator Sergeant Felix Ferranto, using a torch to thaw the wheel motors of the Antarctic Snow Cruiser (August 23, 1940)]] The '''Antarctic Snow Cruiser''' was a vehicle designed from 1937 to 1939 under the direction of [[Thomas Poulter]], intended to facilitate transport in [[Antarctica]]. The Snow Cruiser was also known as "The Penguin," "Penguin 1" or "Turtle"[http://www.joeld.net/snowcruiser/wings_feb_1980.html "The Eagle & the Turtle"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090314053937/http://www.joeld.net/snowcruiser/wings_feb_1980.html |date=March 14, 2009 }}, [[Wings (US magazine)|''Wings'' magazine]]. February, 1980. in some published material. While having several innovative features, it generally failed to operate as hoped under the difficult conditions, and was eventually abandoned in Antarctica. Rediscovered under a deep layer of snow in 1958, it later disappeared again due to shifting ice conditions. ==History== ===Design and construction=== On April 29, 1939, Poulter and ''The Research Foundation of the [[Armour Institute of Technology]]'' showed the plans to officials in [[Washington, D.C.]]. The Research Foundation would finance the cost and oversee the construction, and lend the vehicle to the United States Antarctic Service. Work began on August 8, 1939 and lasted for 11 weeks. On October 24, 1939, the vehicle was fired up for the first time at the Pullman Company just south of Chicago and began the {{convert|1,640|km|mi|abbr=on}} journey to the Boston Army Wharf. During the trip, a damaged steering system caused the vehicle to drive off a small bridge on the [[Lincoln Highway]] and into a stream near the town of [[Gomer, Ohio]] near [[Lima, Ohio]], where it remained for 3 days. After it arrived in [[Boston]], it departed for Antarctica on November 15, 1939 aboard the ship the ''North Star''. ===Arrival in the Antarctic=== The Snow Cruiser arrived at [[Little America (exploration base)|Little America]] in the [[Bay of Whales]], Antarctica with [[United States Antarctic Service Expedition]] in early January 1940 and experienced many problems. It was necessary to construct a ramp from timber to unload the vehicle. As the vehicle was unloaded from the ship, one of the wheels broke through the ramp. The crew cheered when Poulter powered the vehicle free from the ramp but the cheers fell silent when the vehicle failed to move through the snow and ice. The large, smooth, tread-less tires were originally designed for a large swamp vehicle; they spun freely and provided very little forward movement, sinking as much a {{convert|3|ft|m}} into the snow. The crew attached the two spare tires to the front wheels of the vehicle and installed chains on the rear wheels, but were unable to overcome the lack of traction. The crew later found that the tires produced more traction when driven backwards. The longest trek was {{convert|92|mi|km}} – driven completely in reverse. On January 24, 1940, Poulter returned to the US, leaving [[F. Alton Wade]] in charge of a partial crew. The scientists conducted seismologic experiments, cosmic-ray measurements, and ice core sampling while living in the snow- and timber-covered Snow Cruiser. Funding for the project was canceled as the focus in the United States became [[World War II]]. ===Rediscovery and final fate=== During [[Operation Highjump]] in late 1946, an expedition team found the vehicle and discovered it needed only air in the tires and some servicing to make it operational. In 1958, an international expedition uncovered the snow cruiser using a bulldozer. It was covered by several feet of snow but a long bamboo pole marked its position. They were able to dig down to the location of the bottom of the wheels and accurately measure the amount of snowfall since it was abandoned. Inside, the vehicle was exactly as the crew had left it, with papers, magazines, and cigarettes scattered all around. Later expeditions reported no trace of the vehicle. Although there was some unsubstantiated speculation that the (traction-less) Snow Cruiser was taken by the [[Soviet Union]] during the [[Cold War]], the vehicle most likely is either at the bottom of the Southern Ocean or buried deep under snow and ice. Antarctic ice is in constant motion and the ice shelf is constantly moving out to sea. In the mid-1960s, a large chunk of the Ross Ice Shelf broke off and drifted away; the break occurred right through [[Little America (exploration base)|Little America]]. It is not known on which side of the ice shelf the Snow Cruiser was located. ==Vehicle details== {| class="wikitable" |+'''Specifications''' |- ! Attribute ! Description |- |Length |{{convert|17.0|m|ftin|abbr=off|order=flip}} |- |Width |{{convert|6.06|m|ftin|abbr=off||order=flip|sp=us}} |- |Height |Wheels retracted: {{convert|3.7|m|ft|abbr=off||order=flip|sp=us}}
Wheels extended: {{convert|4.9|m|ft|abbr=off||order=flip|sp=us}} |- |Weight (loaded) |{{convert|75000|lb|kg|abbr=on}} |- |Range |{{convert|5000|mi|km}} |- |Maximum Speed |{{convert|30|mph|kph|abbr=on}} |- |Self-Sufficiency |1 year under the most extreme conditions |- |Fuel Capacity |{{convert|2500|gal|l|abbr=off}} stored under the floor |- |Additional Fuel Capacity |{{convert|1000|gal|l|abbr=off}} stored on the roof, to be used by the plane |- |Crew Size |5 people |- |Estimated Cost |$300,000 |- |Cabin Compartments |control cabin, machine shop, combination kitchen/darkroom, fuel storage, food storage, two spare tires |} {| class="wikitable" |+'''Powertrain''' |- ! Attribute ! Description |- |Configuration |[[Diesel-electric transmission|Diesel-Electric Hybrid]] (2 diesel engines, 2 generators, 4 electric motors) |- |Diesel Engine Manufacturer and Model |[[Cummins]] H-6 engine |- |Diesel Engine Power Rating |{{convert|150|hp|kW}} @ 1800 rpm – {{convert|300|hp|kW}} total combined power for 2 engines |- |Diesel Engine Configuration |6-cylinder inline; naturally aspirated |- |Diesel Engine Displacement |{{convert|672|cuin|l|abbr=off}} |- |Diesel Engine Bore and Stroke |{{convert|4+7/8|in|mm|abbr=on}} bore x {{convert|6|in|mm|abbr=on}} stroke |- |Electric Generators |[[General Electric]] |- |Electric Drive Motor Manufacturer |[[General Electric]] |- |Electric Drive Motor Power Rating |{{convert|75|hp|kW}} – {{convert|300|hp|kW}} total combined power for 4 motors |- |Tire Manufacturer |[[Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company]] |- |Tire Dimensions |{{convert|120|in|mm|abbr=on}} outer diameter x {{convert|66|in|mm|abbr=on}} inner diameter x {{convert|33.5|in|mm|abbr=on}} width |} ==Innovative features== {{prose|section|date=May 2014}} *Wheels and tires retracted into housings where they were heated by engine exhaust gases. This was to prevent low-temperature cracking of the natural rubber compound. *Long front and rear overhangs on the body were to assist with crossing crevasses up to {{convert|15|ft|m}} wide. The front wheels were to be retracted so the front could be pushed across the crevasse. The front wheels were then to be extended (and the rear wheels retracted) to pull the vehicle the rest of the way across. This process required a complicated, 20-step procedure. *A pad on top of the vehicle was designed to hold a small aircraft (a 5-passenger Beechcraft biplane.) A winch would pull the aircraft into place. The plane was to be used to conduct aerial surveys. *Engine coolant circulated through the entire cabin for heating. The heating system was very efficient and the crew reported that they needed only light blankets when sleeping. *Excess electrical power could be stored in batteries for running lights and equipment when the engine was not running. *The Diesel-Electric drive train allowed for smaller engines and more space for the crew, due to the elimination of large mechanical drive components throughout the vehicle. This is possibly the first application of a [[Diesel-electric transmission|diesel-electric powertrain]] in a 4-wheeled vehicle of this size; this design is now common in large modern [[dump truck|mining trucks]]. ==See also== * [[United States Antarctic Program]] * [[Snowcat]] * [[Snow coach]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070226065911/http://www.joeld.net/snowcruiser/snowcruiser.html The Antarctic Snow Cruiser] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20061205103239/http://www.joeld.net/snowcruiser/snowhist.html Snow cruiser history] *[http://www.thule.org/snowcruiser.html Reprint of article] from ''[[American Heritage of Invention & Technology|Invention & Technology Magazine]]'' *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070129102944/http://antarcticsun.usap.gov/oldissues99-2000/99_1024/byrdflop.html The Antarctic Edsel] by Bob Hanes *[https://books.google.com/books?id=QywDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA63&dq=Popular+Science+1933+plane+%22Popular+Science%22&hl=en&ei=cTVeTaT1BM25tgfGmMToCw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0CDkQ6AEwBDgo#v=onepage&q&f=true "Planting The Stars And Stripes In The Antarctic"] from ''[[Popular Science]]'' [[Category:All-wheel-drive vehicles]] [[Category:Experimental vehicles]] [[Category:Hybrid vehicles]] [[Category:Snowmobiles]] [[Category:Arctic exploration vessels]] [[Category:History of Antarctica]]

'''Bloso''' was the shortened name for the [[Flanders|Flemish]] [[sport]]s agency. Within [[Belgium]], it was the Flemish counterpart of French-speaking [[ADEPS]]. Both agencies were founded in 1969 to succeed the state-founded national INEPS/NILOS.
In 2016 '''Bloso''' became '''Sport Vlaanderen''' by the merger with the smaller '''departement Sport''', an other sports administration of the Flemish government. The new agency acquired thereby more responsibilities and greater authority on sport in [[Flanders]].
Sport Vlaanderen has several responsibilities:
* support topsport in [[Flanders]] * divide government support funds over the organized sports actors in [[Flanders]] * operate the 13 sports centres of Sport Vlaanderen * organize training and courses for sports trainers * organize [[sports camp]]s * making sport promotion
==External links== *[http://www.sport.vlaanderen/ website Sport Vlaanderen]
[[Category:Sport in Belgium]] [[Category:Flemish government departments and agencies]]

{{About|Brutalist writing|Brutalist architecture|Brutalist_architecture}} '''Brutalism''' is a [[literary movement]] formed in 2006 by three writers from the north of England ([[Tony O'Neill]], [[Adelle Stripe]] and [[Ben Myers]]), and may have been the first literary movement to be launched via the social networking site [[Myspace]] where it announced itself with the following manifesto:
"Brutalism calls for writing that touches upon levels of raw honesty that is a lacking from most mainstream fiction. We cannot simply sit around waiting to be discovered — we would rather do it ourselves. Total control, total creativity. The Brutalists see ourselves as a band who have put down their instruments and picked up their pens and scalpels instead. The only maxim we adhere to is an old punk belief, which we have bastardized for our own means: Here’s a laptop. Here’s a spell-check. Now write a book.."
Brutalist works include ''Digging the Vein'', ''Down and Out on Murder Mile'', ''Seizure Wet Dreams'', and ''Songs from the Shooting Gallery'' by [[Tony O'Neill]], ''Some Things Are Better Left Unsaid'' and ''Cigarettes in Bed'' by [[Adelle Stripe]], and ''The Book of Fuck'', ''[[Richard: A Novel]]'' and ''Pig Iron'' by [[Ben Myers]]. Their debut publication ''Nowhere Fast'' was released as a chapbook on Captains of Industry Press in 2007. The Brutalists are affiliated with the [[Offbeat generation]], a loose association of like-minded writers working across different styles but united by their opposition to a mainstream publishing industry driven by marketing departments. Brutalism 2 ''Cheap Thrills'' was released in summer 2009 as part of [[Mineshaft Magazine]], where a new collection of Brutalist poems featured alongside unpublished work by [[Robert Crumb]] and [[Charles Bukowski]]. ==External links== *O'Neill, Tony. ''Digging the Vein'', Wrecking Ball Press, UK First Edition, 2007. {{ISBN|978-1-903110-18-8}} [https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/1903110181] *O'Neill, Tony. ''Songs from the Shooting Gallery'', Burning Shore Press, US First Edition, 2007. {{ISBN|978-0-9768859-2-4}} [https://www.amazon.com/dp/0976885921] *O'Neill, Tony. ''Down and Out on Murder Mile'', Harper Perennial, US First Edition, 2008. {{ISBN|978-0-06-158286-8}} [https://www.amazon.com/dp/0061582867] *Myers, Ben. ''The Book of Fuck'', Wrecking Ball Press, UK First Edition, 2004. {{ISBN|978-1-903110-15-7}} [https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/1903110157] *Myers, Ben. ''Spam: Emailed Inspired Poetry'', Blackheath Books, UK First Edition 2008. {{ISBN|978-1-906099-07-7}} *Myers, Ben. ''Richard: A Novel'', Picador, UK First Edition 2010. {{ISBN|978-0-330-51703-4}} *Stripe, Adelle. ''Some Things Are Better Left Unsaid'', Blackheath Books, UK First Edition, 2008. {{ISBN|978-1-906099-09-1}} *Stripe, Adelle. ''Cigarettes in Bed'', Blackheath Books, UK First Edition, 2009. {{ISBN|978-1-906099-17-6}} *[https://myspace.com/brutalists The Brutalists' MySpace home] *[http://books.guardian.co.uk/departments/generalfiction/story/0,,2007744,00.html Article about The Brutalists on ''The Guardian'' online edition] *[http://www.wreckingballpress.com/ Wrecking Ball Press, the UK Publishers of 'The Book of Fuck' and 'Digging The Vein] *[http://blogs.guardian.co.uk/books/2007/07/the_rise_and_rise_of_the_bruta.html Article about The Brutalists and Offbeat Generation on ''The Guardian'' online edition] *[http://www.captainsof.com/release_capt045.php/ Captains of Industry Press, UK publishers of The Brutalists] [[Category:British literary movements]] {{UK-stub}} {{lit-mov-stub}}

revision.text:
{{italic title}} '''''Eleutheros Kosmos''''' ({{lang-el|Ελεύθερος Κόσμος}}, ''Free World'') is a [[Greece|Greek]] weekly nationalist newspaper, owned by [[Dimitrios Zaphiropoulos]], which was founded in 2003 as an "independent national newspaper".<ref>As demonstrated by the newspaper's own [http://www.e-grammes.gr/templates/banners/elkosmos.jpg web banner]</ref> Though ideologically distinct, the newspaper bears the same name as the original ''Eleftheros Kosmos'', which was an inspiration for the creation of the new ''Eleftheros Kosmos'' owing to its historical renown among nationalists.<ref>[http://www.e-grammes.gr/article.php?id=2718 "We Will Support Nationalist Candidates: Interview of Demetrios Zafeiropoulos in 'Hellenic Lines'", 9 August 2007]</ref> The original newspaper was in effect the official mouthpiece of the [[Regime of the Colonels]] dictatorship which ruled Greece from 1967 to 1974.
==Lawsuit==
In 2007, the newspaper was sued by the Central Board of Jewish Communities in Greece and the [[Greek Helsinki Monitor]] for "insult of Jews" and "injury to Judaism", stemming from the newspaper's publication of extracts from [[Konstantinos Plevris]]' controversial book ''Jews: The Whole Truth''.<ref>[http://www.elkosmos.gr/site/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=607&Itemid=0 K.I.S. Lawsuit Against "Eleftheros Kosmos" and Konstantinos Plevris, 1 August 2007] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071007205846/http://www.elkosmos.gr/site/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=607&Itemid=0 |date=7 October 2007 }}</ref><ref>[http://www.elkosmos.gr/site/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=596&Itemid=52 Jews Are Bringing Us to Court, 30 July 2007] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071007210039/http://www.elkosmos.gr/site/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=596&Itemid=52 |date=7 October 2007 }}</ref> Both Plevris and ''Eleftheros Kosmos'' characterize the lawsuit as an attempt to suppress free speech. The trial, which was to begin on 5 September, was postponed to 11 September.<ref>[http://elkosmos.gr/site/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=702&Itemid=1 K.I.S. and E.P.S.E Postpone Trial of Eleftheros Kosmos, 5 September 2007] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071007205502/http://elkosmos.gr/site/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=702&Itemid=1 |date=7 October 2007 }}</ref> On 13 December ''Eleftheros Kosmos'' was found not guilty of [[incitement to ethnic or racial hatred|inciting racial hatred]], although the co-accused Plevris was found guilty on first degree. In an appeal on 27 March 2009, K. Plevris was found innocent and acquitted of all charges.<ref>[http://www.darkmoon.me/2013/nterview-with-a-greek-holocaust-denier INTERVIEW WITH A GREEK HOLOCAUST DENIER]</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.elkosmos.gr/ Webpage (Greek only)]
[[Category:Greek-language newspapers]] [[Category:Weekly newspapers published in Greece]] [[Category:Publications established in 2003]]
{{Greece-newspaper-stub}}

[[File:Farafina20090919A.jpg|thumb|Farafina performing in Warszawa in September 2009.]] '''Farafina''' is a music and dance group from [[Burkina Faso]], established in 1978. The eight-member group is Burkina Faso's best known musical group, and one of Africa's most internationally prominent musical groups.[http://www.afropop.org/explore/country_info/ID/24/Burkina%20Faso/]
[http://www.artways.com/artists/farafina/ Farafina] was founded in the southern city of [[Bobo Dioulasso]] by the balafon player [[Mahama Konaté]], a member of the [[Senufo people|Senufo]] ethnic group and a performer with Burkina Faso's national ballet.
The group uses voices and instruments including as the [[balafon]], [[kora (instrument)|kora]], [[djembe]], [[bara (drum)|bara]], [[tama (percussion)|tama]], [doum'doum), [[shekere]], and [[Keyboard instrument|keyboard]].
The group has toured internationally. In 1985 they played at the [[Montreux Jazz Festival]], and in 1988 performed for 72,000 listeners at the birthday party of [[Nelson Mandela]] in [[Wembley Stadium]], [[London]]. In 1993 they toured the United States and Canada, and have performed since then in Europe, Canada, and the United States.
Farafina was one of the groups which played in 1999 in celebration of the 10th anniversary of the House of World Cultures in Berlin. That same year, the group played at the Womad Festival in Singapore.
They have collaborated and recorded with [[Ryuichi Sakamoto]], [[Jon Hassell]], and [[The Rolling Stones]].
A tour is in preparation for Japan and Sweden 2018.
International booking: [http://www.artways.com/artists/farafina/ Artways Productions]
==Discography== *1985 - ''Farafina Live at Montreux Jazz Festival'' *1989 - ''Bolomakote'' *1993 - ''Faso Denou'' *1998 - ''Nemako'' *2001 - ''Kanou'' *2012 - ''Denti Fere'' ===With Ryuichi Sakamoto=== *1989 - ''Beauty'' (three tracks) ===With The Rolling Stones=== *1989 - ''[[Steel Wheels]]'' (on the track "Continental Drift") ===With Jon Hassell=== *1988 - ''Flash of the Spirit''
==External links== *[http://www.artways.com/artists/farafina/ Farafina Official website] *[http://www.artways.com/artists/farafina/ Article about Burkina Faso] ===Listening=== *[http://www.artways.com/artists/farafina/ Farafina audio] ===Video=== *[http://www.artways.com/artists/farafina/ Farafina video]

'''Finlandssvensk samling''' (''Finland-Swedish Association'') is a non-government affiliated organisation in [[Finland]] that strives to protect the [[Language|linguistic]], cultural and human rights of the [[Finland Swedes]]{{citation needed|date=July 2008}}. The [[NGO]] was founded in 2001 by Gösta von Wendt. The membership of the organizastion has drastically increased during the last few years{{citation needed|date=January 2009}}.
It should not be confused with [[Swedish Assembly of Finland]].
== See also == * [[Swedish Assembly of Finland]] * [[Swedish People's Party (Finland)|Swedish People's Party]]
==External links== *[http://www.finlandssvensksamling.org/ Finlandssvensk samling rf]
[[Category:Swedish-speaking Finns]] [[Category:Finland Swedish]] [[Category:Civic and political organisations of Finland]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=July 2018}} {{Infobox airport | name = Gander International Airport | image=Gander International Airport Logo.svg | image2 =Gander_International_Airport_(satellite_view).jpg | caption2 = | WMO = 71803 | IATA = YQX | ICAO = CYQX | type = Public | owner = [[Transport Canada]][http://www.tc.gc.ca/programs/Airports/Status/menu.htm Airport Divestiture Status Report] | operator = Gander International Airport Authority | city-served = [[Gander, Newfoundland and Labrador]] | timezone = [[Newfoundland Time Zone|NST]] | utc = [[UTC−03:30]] | summer = NDT | utcs = [[UTC−02:30]] | elevation-f = 496 | coordinates = {{coord|48|56|13|N|054|34|05|W|region:CA-NL|display=inline,title}} | website = {{URL|http://www.ganderairport.com/}} | image_map = Gander International Airport (CYQX) aero chart.png | image_map_caption = Transport Canada airport diagram | pushpin_map = Canada Newfoundland and Labrador | pushpin_label = CYQX | pushpin_map_caption = Location in [[Newfoundland and Labrador]] | r1-number = 03/21 | r1-length-f = 10,200 | r1-surface = Asphalt | r2-number = 13/31 | r2-length-f = 8,900 | r2-surface = Asphalt | stat-year = 2010 | stat1-header = Aircraft movements | stat1-data = 35,905 | stat2-header = Passengers | stat2-data = 177,532 | footnotes = Sources: [[Canada Flight Supplement]]{{CFS}}
[[Environment Canada]][http://climate.weatheroffice.gc.ca/prods_servs/metstat1_e.html Synoptic/Metstat Station Information] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111201114641/http://climate.weatheroffice.gc.ca/prods_servs/metstat1_e.html |date=December 1, 2011 }}
Movements from [[Statistics Canada]][http://www.statcan.gc.ca/pub/51-209-x/2011001/t002-eng.htm Total aircraft movements by class of operation — NAV CANADA towers]
Passengers from Fly Gander[http://www.ganderairport.com/article/2017passengers/ Total passenger movements] }} '''Gander International Airport''' {{Airport codes|YQX|CYQX}} is located in [[Gander, Newfoundland and Labrador]], Canada, and is operated by the Gander International Airport Authority. [[CFB Gander|Canadian Forces Base Gander]] shares the airfield but is a separate entity from the airport. ==History== ===Early years and prominence=== Construction of the airport began in 1936 and it was opened in 1938, with its first landing on January 11 of that year, by Captain Douglas Fraser flying a [[de Havilland Fox Moth|Fox Moth]] of [[Imperial Airways]]. Within a few years it had four runways and was the largest airport in the world. Its official name until 1949 was '''Newfoundland Airport'''. In 1940, the operation of the Newfoundland Airport was assigned by the [[Dominion of Newfoundland]] to the [[Royal Canadian Air Force]] (RCAF) and it was renamed RCAF Station Gander in 1941. The airfield was heavily used by [[RAF Ferry Command]] and [[Air Transport Command]] for transporting newly built aircraft across the [[Atlantic Ocean]] to the [[European Theatre of World War II|European Theatre]], as well as for staging operational [[Anti-submarine weapon#World War II|anti-submarine patrols]] dedicated to hunting [[U-boat]]s in the northwest Atlantic. Thousands of aircraft flown by the [[United States Army Air Corps]] through [[1941 in aviation#June|the changeover]] to the [[United States Army Air Forces]], and the RCAF destined for the European Theatre, travelled through Gander. The [[Royal Canadian Navy]] (RCN) also established Naval Radio Station Gander at the airfield, using the station as a listening post to detect the transmissions and location of enemy submarines and warships. Following the war, the RCAF handed operation of the airfield back to the dominion government in March 1946, although the RCN's radio station remained and the military role for the entire facility was upgraded through the [[Cold War]]. The Canadian federal government changed the name to Gander Airport after Newfoundland joined Canada in 1949. It opened the current passenger terminal in 1959.{{Cite web|url=http://www.doopedia.co.kr/doopedia/master/master.do?_method=view&MAS_IDX=150330001496262|title=갠더 국제공항|website=www.doopedia.co.kr|language=ko|access-date=April 29, 2018}} ===Transatlantic refueling stop=== On 16 September 1945 the first transatlantic proving flight, a [[Pan American World Airways|Pan Am]] [[Douglas DC-4|DC-4]], departed Gander for [[Shannon Airport|Shannon]] in western [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]].{{cite news|url=http://www.clarelibrary.ie/eolas/coclare/places/airport.htm|title=Shannon Airport|publisher=Clare County Library|accessdate=July 10, 2018}} On 24 October 1945, the first scheduled commercial flight, an [[American Overseas Airlines]] DC-4, passed through Gander. Following Newfoundland's entry into [[Canadian Confederation|Confederation]], the government renamed the airport '''Gander International Airport''' and it came under the administration of Canada's federal [[Transport Canada|Department of Transport]]. Numerous improvements were made to the runways and terminals. Gander is near the [[great circle]] route between cities of the U.S. [[East Coast of the United States|East Coast]] and [[London]]. Starting in the 1940s it was a refueling stop for [[transatlantic flight]]s to Scotland, Ireland, and beyond, and continued in this role through the early 1960s and in some cases into the 1990s. Carriers at Gander during this era included: * [[Aeroflot]] operated [[Ilyushin Il-86]] widebody flights during the 1980s and early 1990s between Moscow and such long-range destinations as New York and Havana (HAV). Due to the IL-86's limited range of approximately {{convert|2,000|mi}}, the flights would make refueling stops at both Shannon and Gander en route to the final destination.https://www.arcadiapublishing.com/Products/9780738564685, Stoff, Joshua, "John F. Kennedy International Airport," p.100 The Boeing 747-200s of the same era had typical ranges from {{convert|5,000|–|6,000|mi}} and were much more sought after by international airlines.Jenkins 2000, p.43 The IL-86 was used almost exclusively by Aeroflot and successor post-Soviet airlines.http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/world/russia/il-86.htm, John Pike, "Il-86 Camber," Retrieved July 28, 2017 * [[Air France]] ran several services through Gander connecting Paris and Shannon to Montreal, Boston, and New York in the 1950s.{{cite web|title=Air France timetable, 1953|url=http://www.timetableimages.com/ttimages/complete/af53/af53-02.jpg|website=Timetableimages.com|accessdate=June 17, 2015}} * [[American Overseas Airlines]] used Gander as a stop for [[Lockheed Constellation]] flights between New York and London from 1947.{{cite web|title=AOA timetable, 1947|url=http://www.timetableimages.com/ttimages/ao1/ao4711/ao47-04.jpg|website=timetableimages.com|accessdate=June 17, 2015}} * [[British Overseas Airways Corporation]] operated Constellations on London-Shannon-Gander-New York, London-Glasgow-Gander-New York, and London-Glasgow-Gander-Montreal routings from 1947.{{cite web|title=BOAC timetable, 1947|url=http://www.timetableimages.com/ttimages/ba2/ba47/ba47-03.jpg|website=timetableimages.com|accessdate=June 17, 2015}} By 1960, the Gander stop was only used as an alternative to a Glasgow or Shannon stop for [[Bristol Britannia]] service to Montreal and Toronto.{{cite web|title=BOAC timetable, 1960|url=http://www.timetableimages.com/ttimages/complete/ba60/ba60-03.jpg|website=timetableimages.com|accessdate=June 17, 2015}} * [[Interflug]] flights between [[East Germany]] and [[Cuba]] would stop to refuel in Gander until the airline began using [[Airbus A310]]s in 1989.{{cite journal|last=Kern|first=Ingolf|title=50 Jahre Interflug: Was von der DDR-Staatsfluggesellschaft blieb|journal=[[Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung]]|date=June 23, 2008|url=http://www.faz.net/aktuell/reise/nah/50-jahre-interflug-was-von-der-ddr-staatsfluggesellschaft-blieb-1547977.html|accessdate=September 19, 2013|language=German}} * [[KLM]] used Gander as a stop on Amsterdam-Glasgow-Gander-New York service from 1946.{{cite web|title=KLM timetable, 1946|url=http://www.timetableimages.com/ttimages/kl/kl46tr/kl46tr-2.jpg|website=timetableimages.com|accessdate=June 17, 2015}} * [[Pan American World Airways]] used Gander as a stop for transatlantic [[Douglas DC-4]] service between [[John F. Kennedy International Airport|New York-Idlewild]] and [[Shannon Airport|Shannon]] (continuing to London and Lisbon) starting in 1946.{{cite web|title=Pan Am timetable, 1946|url=http://www.timetableimages.com/ttimages/pa/pa46/pa46-04.jpg|website=timetableimages.com|accessdate=June 17, 2015}} Gander remained in use in 1960 as a stop for [[Douglas DC-7]] services between New York and Scandinavia, although other transatlantic flights bypassed Gander by that point.{{cite web|title=Pan Am timetable, 1960|url=http://www.timetableimages.com/ttimages/pa/pa60/pa60-04.jpg|website=timetableimages.com|accessdate=June 17, 2015}} * [[Sabena]] operated Brussels-Shannon-Gander-New York service from 1949 using [[Douglas DC-6]]s.{{cite web|title=Sabena timetable, 1949|url=http://www.timetableimages.com/ttimages/complete/sn49/sn49-05.jpg|website=timetableimages.com|accessdate=June 17, 2015}} * [[Scandinavian Airlines]] operated Stockholm-Oslo/Copenhagen-Prestwick-Gander-New York service from 1946.{{cite web|title=SAS timetable, 1946|url=http://www.timetableimages.com/ttimages/sk/sk46/sk46-2.jpg|website=timetableimages.com|accessdate=June 17, 2015}} * [[Trans-Canada Air Lines]] used Gander as a stop for transatlantic service to London from 1946 and also operated local service from Gander to [[St. John's International Airport|St. John's]] and [[Sydney/J.A. Douglas McCurdy Airport|Sydney]].{{cite web|title=Trans-Canada Air Lines timetable, 1946|url=http://www.timetableimages.com/ttimages/ac/tc46/tc46-2.jpg|website=timetableimages.com|accessdate=June 17, 2015}} * [[Trans World Airlines]] operated Boston-Gander-Shannon and Boston-Gander-Azores-Lisbon services from 1947 using Constellations, with onward service to destinations in Europe, the Middle East, and India.{{cite web|title=TWA timetable, 1947|url=http://www.timetableimages.com/ttimages/complete/tw47/tw47-4.jpg|website=timetableimages.com|accessdate=June 17, 2015}} Runway 04/22 was extended from {{Convert|8400|to|10500|ft|-1|abbr=on}} in 1971.''Aviation Daily'' May 21, 1971 p117, November 8, 1971 p47 With the advent of jets with longer range in the 1960s, most flights no longer needed to refuel. Gander has decreased in importance, but it remains the home of [[Gander Control]], one of the two air traffic controls (the other being [[Shanwick Oceanic Control]] in western Ireland) which direct the high-level [[Airway (aviation)|airways]] of the North Atlantic. Most aircraft travelling to and from Europe or [[North America]] must talk to at least one of these [[air traffic control]]s. Some commercial transatlantic flights still use Gander as a refuelling stop; most notably, some American legacy carriers ([[United Airlines]] and [[Delta Air Lines]] in particular) who use the [[Boeing 757]] to connect smaller European cities with their major US hubs.{{cite web|last1=Higgins|first1=Michelle|title=The Flights Are Long. The Planes Are Cramped|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/07/29/travel/29pracsqueeze.html?_r=0|website=New York Times|accessdate=July 29, 2007}} The 757 is particularly affected in this respect, as it was not an aircraft intended or designed for transatlantic flights.{{cite web|last1=Clark|first1=Andrew|title=Continental transatlantic flights run low on fuel|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2008/apr/21/theairlineindustry.useconomy|website=The Guardian|accessdate=April 8, 2008}} This practice has been controversial, since strong headwinds over the Atlantic Ocean during the winter months can result in the flights being declared "minimum fuel", forcing a refuelling stop at Gander in order to safely complete their journey.{{cite web|last1=Paur|first1=Jason|title=High Winds Forcing Pitstops On Transatlantic Flights|url=https://www.wired.com/2012/01/high-winds-forcing-pitstops-on-transatlantic-flights/|website=Wired|accessdate=February 23, 2016}} During the Cold War, Gander was notable for the number of persons from the former [[Warsaw Pact]] nations who defected there (including Soviet chess player and pianist [[Igor Vasilyevich Ivanov]], Cuban Olympic swimmer Rafael Polinario,{{cite web|url=http://www.realjock.com/article/70/|title=Real Athlete: Olympic Swimmer & Water Polo Player Rafael Polinario|first=Andrew|last=Delaware|work=RealJock.com|accessdate=December 17, 2009}} and the Vietnamese woman famously photographed as a naked girl fleeing a napalmed village, [[Phan Thi Kim Phuc]]). It was one of the few refueling points where airplanes could stop en route from Eastern Europe or the [[Soviet Union]] to [[Cuba]]. In 1985, Gander was the site of the [[Arrow Air Flight 1285]] disaster on 12 December, in which a [[Douglas DC-8|McDonnell Douglas DC-8]] with 256 on board crashed during takeoff, probably due to [[atmospheric icing]]; there were no survivors. The crash was, and remains, {{asof|March 2018|lc=true}}, the deadliest airplane accident on Canadian soil. ===Operation Yellow Ribbon=== [[File:Lockheed Hudson - Gander - Royal Air Force Ferry Command, 1941-1943. C2141.jpg|thumb|Lockheed Hudson Mark IIIs are prepared for their trans-Atlantic ferry flights at Gander in 1942]] {{Main|Operation Yellow Ribbon}} On [[September 11, 2001]], with United States airspace closed due to [[September 11, 2001 attacks|the terrorist attacks]], Gander International played host to 38 airliners, totaling 6,122 passengers and 473 crew, as part of Operation Yellow Ribbon. Gander International received more flights than any other Canadian airport involved in the operation apart from [[Halifax Stanfield International Airport|Halifax]]. The 6,595 passengers and crew accounted for the third highest total of passengers that landed at a Canadian airport involved in the operation, behind [[Vancouver International Airport|Vancouver]] and Halifax. A major reason that Gander received so much traffic was its ability to handle large aircraft, and because [[Transport Canada]] and [[Nav Canada]] instructed pilots coming from Europe to avoid the airports in major urban centres of Central Canada, like [[Toronto Pearson International Airport]] and [[Montréal-Pierre Elliott Trudeau International Airport|Montréal-Dorval]].{{cite web |year=2009 |url = http://www.navcanada.ca/NavCanada.asp?Language=en&Content=ContentDefinitionFiles\Newsroom\Backgrounders\911crisis.xml|title = NAV CANADA and the 9/11 Crisis|publisher = [[Nav Canada]]| accessdate = March 19, 2009 | last= |quote=}} The reception these travellers received in the central Newfoundland communities near the airport has been one of the most widely reported happy stories surrounding that day, and was dramatized in the musical ''[[Come from Away]]''. To honour the people of Gander and [[Halifax Regional Municipality|Halifax]] for their support during the operation, [[Lufthansa]] named a new [[Airbus A340#A340-300|Airbus A340-300]] "Gander/Halifax" on May 16, 2002. That airplane is listed with the registration D-AIFC,[http://www.airliners.net/search/photo.search?front=yes&maxres=500&keywords=D-AIFC D-AIFC at] [[airliners.net]] and was the first aircraft of that fleet with a city name from outside of Germany. The airport was the site for Canada's memorial service to mark the [[Memorials and services for the September 11 attacks|first anniversary of the attack]], over which [[Prime Minister of Canada|Prime Minister]] [[Jean Chrétien]], [[Minister of Transport (Canada)|Transport Minister]] [[David Collenette]], [[United States Ambassador to Canada|US Ambassador to Canada]] [[Paul Cellucci]], and provincial and local officials presided. 2,500 of the 6,600 people that were diverted there the year before also attended the ceremony. ==Future growth== Officials at Gander International Airport have stated that the future for the airport is grim unless the [[Government of Canada|federal government]] provides funding to cover costs. Over 50% of all aircraft operating from the air field are military, and do not pay [[landing fee]]s.[http://www.cbc.ca/canada/newfoundland-labrador/story/2006/07/20/gander-airport.html Gander airport warns it could close without Ottawa's help] However, domestic passenger traffic increased by over seven percent in 2006, while weekly cargo flights from [[Iceland]] show some promise of expansion. In April 2014, Gander Airport Authority decided on plans to abandon the existing terminal building due to high operating costs and replace it with a new terminal a quarter of the size. The fate of the old building is uncertain. The terminal, which was built in the 1950s and has drawn continuing worldwide interest for its modernist design, has been recognized by other Canadian institutions as a valuable piece of heritage architecture and has many of its original furnishings and fixtures still intact.{{cite web |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/newfoundland-labrador/gander-airport-to-be-traded-in-for-new-terminal-1.2624909 |title=Gander airport to be traded-in for new terminal |date=April 29, 2014 |publisher=CBC News}} Early in 2016 it was revealed that Gander Airport would be losing WestJet Encore flights with service to Halifax International Airport, to Deer Lake Regional Airport due to low passenger numbers for the Q-400 operated flights, but however reinstated its flight in May 2017 and as well dropped its mainline flight to Toronto. ==Facilities== [[File:Gander Airport - runway.jpg|thumb|Runway at Gander International Airport]] ===Runways=== Gander has two active [[runway]]s: runway 13/31 which is {{Convert|8900|x|200|ft|abbr=on|0}}, and runway 03/21 (changed from 04/22 in August 2004) which measures {{Convert|10500|x|200|ft|abbr=on|0}} and undergone a $10 million comprehensive rehabilitation project completed in September 2012. The airport's runway 03/21 was designated as an emergency landing runway for NASA's [[Space Shuttle|Space Shuttle orbiter]]. The airport is also an important emergency landing runway for large aircraft in transatlantic operation in the [[ETOPS]] system, which requires aircraft to always have less than a certain distance from a suitable landing site.[http://code7700.com/pdfs/icao_annex_6_part_i.pdf Annex 6 – Operation of Aircraft] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170329071416/http://code7700.com/pdfs/icao_annex_6_part_i.pdf |date=March 29, 2017 }} For many two-engine aircraft this is two or three hours with malfunction in one engine. ===Fire services=== Gander Airport Safety and Airside Operations is responsible for fire and rescue operations using three vehicles at their station within the airport. It also has a mutual aid agreement with the Town of Gander Fire Department to provide additional fire fighting services.http://www.firefightingincanada.com/emergency-disaster-management/the-status-of-airport-security-9601 The airport fire crew is a mix of full-time and volunteers with total crew of 14. ==Airlines and destinations== {{Airport-dest-list | [[Air Canada Express]] | [[CFB Goose Bay|Goose Bay]], [[Halifax Stanfield International Airport|Halifax]], [[St. John's International Airport|St. John's]], [[Wabush Airport|Wabush]]
'''Seasonal''': [[Toronto Pearson International Airport|Toronto-Pearson]] | [[Exploits Valley Air Services|Exploits Valley Air]] | [[Fogo Aerodrome|Fogo]] | [[Miami Air International]] | '''Charter:''' [[Miami International Airport|Miami]] | [[PAL Airlines]] | [[Churchill Falls Airport|Churchill Falls]], [[CFB Goose Bay|Goose Bay]], [[St. John's International Airport|St. John's]], [[Wabush Airport|Wabush]] | [[Sunwing Airlines]] | '''Seasonal:''' [[Toronto Pearson International Airport|Toronto-Pearson]], [[Juan Gualberto Gómez Airport|Varadero]] | [[WestJet Encore]] | [[Halifax Stanfield International Airport|Halifax]] }} ==Fixed-base operators (FBOs)== The following [[fixed-base operator]]s are based at Gander International Airport: ===Public=== * Allied Aviation * Woodward Aviation * Gander Aviation * [[Irving Group of Companies|Irving Aviation Services]] * [[Royal Dutch Shell|Shell Aviation]] * GFT Aviation Services ===Military=== * Woodward's Oil Limited ==Accidents and incidents== Since the airport's founding in 1938 and through the course of [[World War II]] and subsequent beginnings of transoceanic air travel, there have been dozens of crashes around Gander of fighters, bombers, freighters, sea planes, radar aircraft, civilian airliners and private craft. [[File:PBY over DC-4 crashsite Newfoundland 1946.jpeg|thumb|right|The crash site of the DC-4 on [[Newfoundland (island)|Newfoundland]].]] *On 21 February 1941, three people were killed when a [[Lockheed L-14 Super Electra]]/[[Lockheed Hudson|Hudson]] departing from Gander crashed near [[Musgrave Harbour]] after both of the plane's engines failed. The fatalities include [[Frederick Banting|Sir Frederick Grant Banting]] who died of wounds and exposure. The navigator and co-pilot died instantly, but Banting and the pilot, Captain [[Mackey Airlines|Joseph Mackey]], survived the initial impact. According to Mackey, the sole survivor, Banting died from his injuries the next day.{{cite book |last=Stevens |first=James |date=July 6, 2006 |title=The Maw: Searching for the Hudson Bombers |publisher= Trafford |pages=41–43 |isbn=978-1412063845}} *On 18 September 1946, 27 people lost their lives when a [[Sabena|SABENA]] [[Douglas DC-4]] (OO-CBG) crashed 35 km short of Gander Airport, where the aircraft planned to land for a refueling stop on the flight from Brussels to New York. At the time of the accident (07:42 [[Coordinated Universal Time|UTC]]), there was dense fog near the airport, and the pilot executed a flawed approach at too low an altitude. There were 17 survivors (16 passengers and one crew).{{cite web|url=http://aviation-safety.net/database/record.php?id=19460918-0 |title=ASN Aircraft accident Douglas DC-4-1009 OO-CBG Gander, NF |publisher=Aviation-safety.net |date=September 18, 1946 |accessdate=July 23, 2014}} *On 5 September 1967 an [[Ilyushin Il-18]] (registration OK-WAI) of [[Czech Airlines|Ceskoslovenske Aerolinie (ČSA)]] Flight 523 crashed on climbout heading east on runway 13 while on a Prague-Shannon-Gander-Havana passenger service, killing 37 of 69 on board; the cause was never determined.{{ASN accident |title= OK-WAI |id=19670905-0 |accessdate=September 23, 2013}} *On 12 December 1985 [[Arrow Air Flight 1285]] crashed on take-off from the then runway 22. The disaster claimed the lives of 8 crew and 248 soldiers of the [[United States Army]]'s [[101st Airborne Division (United States)|101st Airborne Division]] who were returning home for Christmas from a [[peacekeeping]] deployment in the [[Middle East]]. The impact on the south side of the [[Trans-Canada Highway]] on the shore of [[Gander Lake]] left a charred clearing in the forest where a memorial now stands to those who lost their lives in Canada's most deadly air crash.{{ASN accident|id=19851212-0}} *On 31 March 2007, an [[Antonov An-124 Ruslan]] operated by [[Volga-Dnepr Airlines]] inbound from [[Greer, South Carolina]], landed on runway 03/21 but failed to stop and ran off the runway.{{cite news|url=http://www.tsb.gc.ca/ENG/rapports-reports/aviation/2007/a07a0029/a07a0029.asp|title=Aviation Investigation Report A07A0029|publisher=Transportation Safety Board of Canada |accessdate=July 5, 2018}} ==See also== {{Portal|World War II}} *[[North Atlantic Aviation Museum]] ==References== {{Reflist}} *{{Air Force Historical Research Agency}}{{title missing|date=August 2017}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Gander International Airport}} *[http://www.ganderairport.com/ Gander International Airport] *[http://www.snopes.com/rumors/gander.htm Tales of Gander hospitality on September 11 (snopes.com)] {{Can-arpt-wx|CYQX|Gander International Airport}} *{{ASN|YQX|Gander International Airport}} * NBC News feature featuring Tom Brokaw: [http://www.clipsyndicate.com/video/play/1335538/gander_brokaw_piece?wpid=5435 "A Tribute to Gander, Newfoundland "], February 27, 2010 * New York Times travel article. Gollner, Adam. [http://travel.nytimes.com/2005/03/20/travel/tmagazine/20TGANDER.html "Gander Airport: When the Going Was Good"], March 20, 2005 {{List of airports in Canada}} {{USAAF Antisubmarine Command}} [[Category:Certified airports in Newfoundland and Labrador]] [[Category:Airports established in 1938]] [[Category:Gander, Newfoundland and Labrador]] [[Category:WAAS reference stations]] [[Category:Airfields of the United States Army Air Forces Air Transport Command on the North Atlantic Route]] [[Category:1938 establishments in Newfoundland]] [[Category:National Airports System]]

revision.text:
{{hatnote|For the British boxer, see [[Gary Davies (boxer)]]. For people with a similar name, see [[Gareth Davies (disambiguation)]] or [[Gary Davies (disambiguation)]]}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2016}} {{Use British English|date=February 2016}} {{BLP sources|date=April 2011}} {{Infobox person | name = Gary Davies | image = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1957|12|13|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Manchester]], [[Lancashire]], England | nationality = British | years_active = 1979–present | known_for = Radio and TV presenter | education = | employer = [[BBC]] | television = ''[[Top Of The Pops]]'' | spouse = | children = | relatives = }} '''Gary Davies''' (born 13 December 1957, [[Manchester]], England) is an English [[Television presenter|broadcaster]]. During the 1980s and early 1990s he was a [[BBC Radio 1]] [[disc jockey]]<ref name="Randall2000">{{cite book|last=Randall|first=Mac|title=Exit Music: The Radiohead Story|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gTIdKqWJIyoC&pg=PT71|accessdate=10 April 2011|date=2000-09-12|publisher=Random House Digital, Inc.|isbn=978-0-385-33393-1|page=71}}</ref> and a regular presenter of ''[[Top of the Pops]]''. As of 2018 he can be heard on [[BBC Radio 2]].
==Early career== After working in marketing for a mail order company and managing a Manchester disco, Davies began his broadcasting career at Manchester's [[Piccadilly Radio]] in 1979 before joining [[BBC Radio 1]] in 1982 to present a Saturday late night show, making his debut on 4 December 1982. Within weeks he was on the roster to present ''[[Top Of The Pops]]'' on BBC television alongside his Radio 1 colleagues.
==BBC Radio 1==
===The Bit in the Middle=== In 1984, Davies was given the slot for which he became one of radio's biggest stars when he took over the Radio 1 lunchtime show. He called it ''The Bit In The Middle'' and it consisted of features, such as ''The Day-To-Day Challenge'', in which the same person would go on air each weekday to answer quiz questions and try to upgrade their prize, and ''Willy On The Plonker'', which involved a crazed [[piano]]-playing of a well-known hit for listeners to identify.
The show was hugely important in the 1980s as at the time the new [[UK Singles Chart|UK Top 40]] was announced on Tuesday afternoons. On Sunday 6 September 1987, for one time only he presented the Sunday Afternoon Stereo Countdown of the Top 40 from 5{{nbsp}}pm to 7{{nbsp}}pm filling in for Bruno Brookes.
The show always ended with the instrumental section of The Look of Love by ABC from the album The Lexicon of Love.
There was a [[marketing|marketability]] about Davies as he was regarded by some female listeners as a heart-throb. He was projected as an eligible [[bachelor]] of the station, complete with a catchphrase "Young, Free and Single" and a [[jingle]] "Wooh! Gary Davies".<ref name="Radio Rewind">{{cite web|url=http://www.radiorewind.co.uk/radio1/gary_davies_page.htm|title=Radio Rewind: Gary Davies page}}</ref>
Davies became popular on the Radio 1 roadshows throughout the 1980s but his own show rarely changed until it was rebranded in 1991 as ''Let's Do Lunch'', with new features, including ''Spin & Win'' (a variation on ''Willy On The Plonker'', with a cryptic clue replacing the frenetic piano work) and the ''Classic Track'', which was the one time of the week Radio 1 played a piece of classical music. Previous feature ''The Sloppy Bit'' (a dedication followed by love song) was unchanged but renamed ''Lots Of Love''. He also introduced The Non Stop Half Hour from after the 2.30{{nbsp}}pm news until 3{{nbsp}}pm, which was half an hour of non stop music.
With updated technology, the chart rundown was moved forward to Sundays from 4 October 1987 onwards. Instead, Davies did countdowns of the US chart and the UK album chart — although the US chart he featured was not the official ''[[Billboard magazine|Billboard]]'' one, but an airplay-only chart compiled by ''[[Radio and Records]]'' magazine.
===Weekends=== In 1992, Davies quit the lunchtime show and moved to weekend breakfast, keeping a selection of the features. He also started a Sunday late night slot. The ''Lots of Love'' feature moved to this show, with dedications being read out over the music to ''[[Dances with Wolves]]''. During this period, he could also be heard deputising for weekday presenters when taking their holidays, usually [[Steve Wright (DJ)|Steve Wright]] or [[Nicky Campbell]].
===Leaving Radio 1=== In 1993, with a new regime at Radio 1 wishing to squeeze out the older presenters representing a past era, Davies was sacked. His last record was ''[[Layla]]'' by [[Eric Clapton|Derek and the Dominoes]] — which had also been his first record on the station eleven years earlier.{{citation needed|date=October 2016}}
The last two years of Davies' Radio 1 career allowed him the opportunity to display his love of music; higher-profile shows often negated the need for DJs to be heard caring for the songs they were playing, concentrating instead on the personality side of the programming. Davies got his opportunity to display his musical knowledge - he was, for example, the first DJ to play [[Radiohead]] on Radio 1, when a copy of their [[Drill (EP)|Drill EP]] was sent to him.
Davies was also the last Radio 1 DJ to host [[Top of the Pops]] before the show's "year zero" re-vamp in October 1991.
==Virgin Radio== In January 1994, Davies moved to [[Virgin Radio]], presenting their Sunday morning ''Classic Tracks'' slot from 10{{nbsp}}am to 2{{nbsp}}pm. The show later went out from 9{{nbsp}}am to 1{{nbsp}}pm and he remained there until early 1995.
After a brief sabbatical, Davies then rejoined Virgin Radio in December 1995, taking over the Sunday late night show from 10{{nbsp}}pm to 2{{nbsp}}am. This gave him the chance to revive his Sunday night format. Davies then went on to present the weekday late night slot in January 1999, where he remained until December 2000.
==Recent work== Davies was heard on the [[Real Radio]] and the [[Century Radio]] network, presenting a CD chart show every Sunday originally from 1 to 4{{nbsp}}pm but from 2006 the show went out from 4{{nbsp}}pm to 7{{nbsp}}pm. However, this finished in mid-2008. Currently{{when|date=November 2011}} he owns a publishing company called Good Groove, where he also manages new artists. Good Groove's 1st publishing hit was Black Coffee by All Saints and Davies later went on to sign singer Corinne Bailey Rae. <ref name="LinkedIn">{{cite web |url=http://uk.linkedin.com/pub/gary-davies/24/7b7/455 |title=Gary Davies - United Kingdom | LinkedIn |publisher=Uk.linkedin.com |date= |accessdate=2014-06-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20121209214948/http://uk.linkedin.com/pub/gary-davies/24/7b7/455 |archivedate=9 December 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
On 9 June 2017, Davies stood in for [[Sara Cox]] to present a special 2¾ hour edition of Sounds of the 80s on [[BBC Radio 2]]. This was his first time back on BBC Radio for 23 years.<ref name="BBC">{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b08s76yd |title=Gary Davies sits in |publisher=BBC |date= |accessdate=2017-06-09}}</ref><ref name="Radio-Today">{{cite web|url=https://radiotoday.co.uk/2017/05/presenter-gary-davies-returns-to-bbc-radio/#BBCRadio2 |title=Presenter Gary Davies returns to BBC Radio |publisher=Radio Today UK |date= |accessdate=2017-06-09}}</ref> In October 2017, January 2018 & October 2018 Davies sat in for [[Steve Wright (DJ)|Steve Wright]]'s BBC Radio 2 [[Steve Wright in the Afternoon|show]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://radiotoday.co.uk/2017/10/gary-davies-back-on-daily-show-with-radio-2/ |title=Gary Davies back on daily show with Radio 2 |publisher=Radio Today UK |date= |accessdate=2017-10-10}}</ref> On 18 May 2018, Davies took over from Sara Cox as host of Radio 2 Sounds of the 80s.<ref name="MANGaryReturn">{{cite web|url= https://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/news/showbiz-news/gary-davies-bbc-radio-2-14649460 |accessdate = 22 June 2018 | work = Manchester Evening News | date = 18 May 2018 | title = Ooh Gary Davies! The Manchester DJ legend on his BBC return and how it all started at The Twisted Wheel |first = Dianne | last = Bourne |language=en-GB}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *{{bbc programme|b03c936z|Sounds of the 80s}}

This is a '''list of gurdwaras in Asia''', excluding [[List of gurdwaras|gurdwaras in India and Pakistan]], the birthplace of [[Sikhism]].
A [[gurdwara]] is a place of worship within Sikhism. Three activities carried out in all gurdwaras are: * [[Kirtan]] - the singing of devotional hymns from the [[Guru Granth Sahib]] * Readings from the Guru Granth Sahib * [[Langar (Sikhism)|Langar]] - free meals for all visitors, whether [[Sikh]] or not.
{{dynamic list}}
==Afghanistan== *Jalalabad (Nangarhar Province) **Gurdwara Shri Guru Tegh Bahadur Jalalabad **Gurdwara Guru Nanak Dev Ji, Jalalabad **Gurdwara Shri Guru Tegh Bahadur, Jalalabad *Kabul **Gurdwara Baba Nanak, Jade Mewan, Kabul **Gurdwara Baba Sri Chand, Kabul **Gurdwara Shor Bazar, Kabul **[[Gurdwara Karte Parwan]], Kabul **Gurdwara Khalsa Shor Bazar, Kabul **Gurdwara Koth Sahib, Kabul *Other **Gurdwara Bhai Nand Lal Goya, Ghazni **Gurdwara Kotha Sahib, Ghazni **Gurdwara Khalsa Diwan, Chashma Sahib, Sultanpur **Gurdwara Guru Har Rai
==Bangladesh== [[Image:Gurdwara NanakShahi Dhaka by Ragib Hasan.jpg|right|thumb|Gurdwara Nanak Shahi, [[Dhaka University]] Campus, Bangladesh.]] *Dhaka **Gurdwara Guru Nanak, Chowk Bazar **[[Gurdwara Nanak Shahi]] {{coord|23.733557 |N |90.393807| E}} **Gurdwara Sangat Tola {{coord| 23.706772 |N |90.414688 |E}} **Gurdwara Sri Guru Tegh Bahadur *Chittagong **Sikh Temple Chowk Bazaar **Sikh Temple Punjabi Lane Phahartali *Mymensingh **Gurdwara Sahib Shivpuri
==Burma== * All Burma Sikh Religious Council * Central Burma Sikh Missionary * Sikh Temple * Sikh Temple, Myanmar * Burma Sikh Missionary *Sikh temple Myitkyina Kachin State *Young Men Sikh Association (Myitkyina) *Gurudwara Sahib, Monwyan, Dawnachan *Sikh Temple Main Road, Lai Kha, Southern Shan State *Gurudwara Sahib, Yonegone Village, Pyawbwe Town, Mandalay region *Gurudwara Sabib, Pyawbwe Shwe Pyi Yan Lane quarter (Yangon) *Gurudwara Sahib Pathein (190 km from Yangon) *Sikh Temple, Taung Dwin Gyi *Gurudwara Sahib, Taunggyi *Gurudwara Sahib Shweboi, Sagaing region (113 km from Mandalay) *Central Burma Sikh Missionary, Mandalay *Gurudwara Sahib, Bhamo *Gurudwara Sahib Kalaw *Gurudwara Sahib Tala, Thukra Road, Block (2), Lollem, Southern Shan State Sikh Temple Kengtung, Si Dan Street (Opp 'Happy Cafe') Kyaing Tong, Eastern Shan State
==China== *Shanghai Gurdwara<ref name="sikhnn">{{cite web|url=http://www.sikhnn.com/headlines/1386/secluded-gurdwara-china|title=The Secluded Gurdwara in China|author=Kaur, Anju|publisher=SIKHnn.com|date=May 6, 2011}}</ref> *Yiwi Gurdwara<ref name="sikhnn"/>
==Indonesia== *Special Capital Region of [[Jakarta]] **Guru Nanak Sikh Temple. Gurdwara Tanjung Priok, North Jakarta (www.gurdwara-tgpriok.com) **The Sikh Gurdwara Mission at Pasar Baru, Central Jakarta *Banten Province **Gurdwara Dharma Khalsa at Ciledug, Tangerang City (Closed In 2015) **Yayasan Sosial Guru Nanak at Ciputat, South Tangerang City *East Java Province **Gurdwara at Surabaya *[[North Sumatra]] Province **Medan ***Gurdwara Guru Arjan Dev Ji ***Gurdwara Misi Shree Guru Tegh Bahadur ***Gurdwara at Sri Guru Nanak Dev Ji ***Gurdwara at Kampung Anggrung **Binjai ***Gurdwara Shree Guru Gobind Singh Jee **Siantar ***Shree Guru Nanak Dev Ji Gurdwara **Tebing Tinggi ***Gurdwara Sri Guru Granth Sahib Ji *[[South Sumatra]] Province **Gurdwara at Palembang
There are two cities in Indonesia which are the main residence of Sikh community, Medan in first place followed by Jakarta. There was a Gurdwara in Aceh Province, but already closed several years ago. Some of the Sanggat moved to Medan, and the rest was unknown. There was also Sikh community in Padang city, but there's no indicated that a Gurdwara was built there, and the community is unknown.
==Iran== *Tehran **[[Masjid-e-Hindan]] **Gurdwara Sahib *Zahidan, Baluchistan **Sikh Temple
==Iraq== *Baghdad **Gurdwara Baba Nanak show the picture and history of the gurdwara

{{Infobox company | name = Impulse Music Travel | logo =Impulse Retailer Logo.jpg | fate = | type = [[Private limited company|Private]] | genre = | foundation = March 1994 | founder = | defunct = | location_city = [[Hertfordshire]] | location_country = [[United Kingdom]] | location = | locations = 24 | area_served = | key_people = Les Whitfield, Managing Director (1994-2007) | industry = Entertainment [[Retail]] | products = [[CD]]s
[[DVD]]s
[[Game]]s
[[Music]] | services = | market cap = | revenue = £9 million (2007) | operating_income = | net_income = | assets = | equity = | owner = | num_employees = 150{{Cite web |url=http://www.accessmylibrary.com/coms2/summary_0286-10822418_ITM |title=Receiver optimistic on finding Impulse buyer |publisher=Music Week |date=2001-04-01 |accessdate=2009-02-18}} | parent = Impulse Music Travel Limited | divisions = | subsid = | homepage = | footnotes = | intl = }} '''Impulse Music Travel''' is an [[entertainment]] retail chain in the [[United Kingdom]], with 24 concessions in various UK airports and railway stations. The company was formed in March 1994. In July 2007, Managing Director Les Whitfield sold the company.{{Cite web |url=http://www.linkedin.com/pub/a/820/274 |title=Les Whitfield’s Summary |publisher=LinkedIn |accessdate=2009-02-18}} == History == The company was formed in March 1994 and entered into [[Administration (law)|administration]] on 21 March 2001 with [[BDO Stoy Hayward LLP|BDO Stoy Hayward]]. Ray Stocking, joint administrator of Impulse Music Travel, said the rapid expansion of the chain was one of the reasons why it had forced the company into administration. The company was brought out of administration and sold in July 2007. There are currently 24 Impulse locations across the [[United Kingdom]]. == Operations == In the 1990s, the company operated the [[Selfridges]], in London, and [[Fenwicks]], in [[Newcastle upon Tyne|Newcastle]], computer departments.{{Cite web |url=http://www.accountancyage.com/crn/news/2001151/oxford-street-home-second-software-city |title=Oxford Street home for second Software City |publisher=Accountancy Age |date=1996-11-08 |accessdate=2009-02-18}} Other store locations previously included Burnley, Darlington, Hartlepool and Macclesfield, and King's Cross and Marylebone railway stations. The original concessions and retail outlets were designed by Mark Homer Design - www.markhomerdesign.co.uk Today, Impulse operates concessions at Birmingham Airport, London Luton Airport, Manchester Airport formed through contracts with BAA. == Product range == Impulse Music Travel concessions mainly stock [[compact disc|CDs]], [[DVDs]] and [[Video Games]]. == See also == * [[Head Entertainment]] == References == {{Reflist|2}} [[Category:Retail companies of the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Retail companies established in 1994]] {{unitedkingdom-stub}}

{{coord|0|-55|display=title}} {{Infobox spaceflight | name = Intelsat 604 | image = | image_caption = | mission_type = [[Communications satellite|Communication]] | operator = [[Intelsat]] | website = | COSPAR_ID = 1990-056A{{cite web|url=http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/spacecraftDisplay.do?id=1990-056A|title=INTELSAT 6 F-4|publisher=US National Space Science Data Center|accessdate=13 July 2012}} | SATCAT = 20667 | mission_duration = 13 years (planned)
16 years (achieved) | spacecraft_bus = [[HS-389]] | manufacturer = [[Hughes Aircraft|Hughes]] | dry_mass = | launch_mass = {{convert|4215|kg}} | power = | launch_date = {{start-date|23 June 1990, 11:19|timezone=yes}} UTC | launch_rocket = [[Commercial Titan III|CT-III]]/[[Orbus-21S]] CT-3 | launch_site = [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station|Cape Canaveral]] [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station Space Launch Complex 40|LC-40]] | launch_contractor = [[Martin Marietta]] | entered_service = | disposal_type = Decommissioned | deactivated = {{end-date|6 April 2006}} | orbit_epoch = 26 July 1990 | orbit_reference = [[Geocentric orbit|Geocentric]] | orbit_regime = [[Geostationary orbit|Geostationary]] | orbit_periapsis = {{convert|35692|km}} | orbit_apoapsis = {{convert|35887|km}} | orbit_inclination = 0.3 degrees | orbit_period = 1436.24 minutes | orbit_longitude = | apsis = gee | trans_band = | trans_frequency = | trans_capacity = | trans_coverage = | trans_TWTA = | trans_EIRP = | trans_HPBW = | programme = ''[[Intelsat VI]]'' | previous_mission = [[Intelsat 603|Intelsat VI F-3]] | next_mission = [[Intelsat 605|Intelsat VI F-5]] }} '''Intelsat 604''', previously named '''Intelsat VI F-4''', was a [[communications satellite]] operated by [[Intelsat]]. Launched in 1990, it was the third of five [[Intelsat VI]] satellites to be launched. The Intelsat VI series was constructed by [[Hughes Aircraft]], based on the [[HS-389]] [[satellite bus]]. Intelsat 604 was launched at 11:19 UTC on 23 June 1990, atop a [[Commercial Titan III]] carrier rocket, flight number CT-3, with an [[Orbus-21S]] upper stage.{{cite web|url=http://planet4589.org/space/log/launchlog.txt|title=Launch Log|publisher=Jonathan's Space Page|first=Jonathan|last=McDowell|accessdate=13 July 2012}} The launch took place from [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station Space Launch Complex 40|Launch Complex 40]] at [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station]],{{cite web|url=http://planet4589.org/space/lvdb/list2.html|title=Launch List|publisher=Jonathan's Space Page|work=Launch Vehicle Database|first=Jonathan|last=McDowell|accessdate=13 July 2012}} and successfully placed Intelsat 604 into a [[geosynchronous transfer orbit]]. The satellite raised itself into its final [[geostationary orbit]] using two liquid-fuelled [[R-4D-12]] engines,{{cite web|url=http://space.skyrocket.de/doc_sdat/intelsat-6.htm|title=Intelsat-6 (601, 602, 603, 604, 605)|first=Gunter|last=Krebs|work=Gunter's Space Page|accessdate=13 July 2012}} with the satellite arriving in geostationary orbit on 28 June 1990.{{cite web|url=http://planet4589.org/space/log/geo.date|title=Index|publisher=Jonathan's Space Page|work=Geostationary Orbit Catalog|first=Jonathan|last=McDowell|accessdate=13 July 2012}} Intelsat 604 initially operated in a geostationary orbit with a [[apsis|perigee]] of {{convert|35692|km}}, an [[apsis|apogee]] of {{convert|35887|km}}, and 0.3 degrees of [[inclination]],{{cite web|url=http://planet4589.org/space/log/satcat.txt|title=Satellite Catalog|publisher=Jonathan's Space Page|first=Jonathan|last=McDowell|accessdate=13 July 2012}} however over time this became more inclined. The satellite carried 38 IEEE [[C band (IEEE)|C band]] and ten IEEE {{Ku band}} [[transponder]]s, and had a design life of 13 years and a mass of {{convert|4215|kg}}. Following its arrival in geostationary orbit, Intelsat 604 was deployed at a longitude of 38 degrees west. It was moved to 27.5 degrees west in January 1991, where it operated until February 1992. From October 1992 to March 2002, it was operated at 60 degrees east. After leaving this position, it was positioned at 157 degrees east from August 2002 to September 2005. Its final deployment was from February to March 2006, at 177.85 degrees. The satellite was decommissioned on 6 April 2006 after it had been moved to a [[graveyard orbit]].{{cite web|url=http://www.tbs-satellite.com/tse/online/sat_intelsat_604.html|title=Intelsat 604|publisher=tbs Internet|work=The Satellite Encyclopedia|date=3 July 2012|accessdate=13 July 2012}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{Portal|Spaceflight}} {{Intelsat}} {{Orbital launches in 1990}} [[Category:Intelsat satellites]] [[Category:Hughes aircraft]] [[Category:Spacecraft launched in 1990]] [[Category:Derelict satellites orbiting Earth]]

[[File:FIESA 7 overview 258.jpg|thumb|'''FIESA 2009:''' Discoveries]] Described as the largest [[sand sculpture]] event in the world,{{cite web|url=http://www.euroweeklynews.com|title=The world’s biggest sand sculpture event is under way|date=6 July 2007|work=Euro Weekly News|accessdate=2 May 2010|location=Spain}}{{cite web|url=http://thestar.com.my/lifestyle/story.asp?file=/2008/5/28/lifefocus/21334133&sec=lifefocus|title=All star cast : International Sand Sculpture Festival|date=28 May 2008|work=The Star|accessdate=2 May 2010|location=Malaysia}}{{cite web|url=http://theartinquirer.blogspot.com/2009/05/sand-sculptures-fiesa-2009.html|title=Sand Sculpture - FIESA 2009|date=25 May 2009|work=The Art Inquirer|accessdate=2 May 2010}} the '''International Sand Sculpture Festival''' or '''Festival Internacional de Escultura em Areia''' (FIESA) has been held in [[Pêra (Silves)|Pêra]], [[Algarve]], [[Portugal]] annually since 2003. The site at {{coord|37.1289|N|8.3310|W|region:PT|display=it}} occupies {{convert|15000|m2|acre}}. Each year about 60 artists use 35000 tons of sand to create 50 works of art. The exhibition is also open in the evenings with atmospheric lighting.[http://www.algarveguidebook.com/index.php?page=fiesa Algarve Guide Book] == Themes == [[File:FIESA 7 Freud 276.jpg|thumb|250|Sigmund Freud with a patient (FIESA 2009)]] Each year the exhibition has a different theme:[http://www.fiesa.org FIESA website] '''2014:''' Music II
'''2013:''' Music
'''2012:''' Idols
'''2011:''' Animal Kingdom
'''2010:''' Living World
'''2009:''' Discoveries
'''2008:''' Hollywood Films and Characters
'''2007:''' Wonders of the World
'''2006:''' Mythology
'''2005:''' Lost Worlds
'''2004:''' Tales of Enchantment == See also == * [[Sand festival]] ==References== {{Reflist}} == External links == {{Commons category|position=left|FIESA|
FIESA
(International Sand Sculpture Festival)}} [[Category:Art festivals in Portugal]] [[Category:Sand art]] [[Category:Outdoor sculptures in Portugal]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in the Algarve]] [[Category:Annual events in Portugal]] [[Category:Recurring events established in 2003]] [[Category:2003 establishments in Portugal]] {{-}} {{Portugal-stub}}

Sagarika Music Pvt. Ltd.
Kosmic Music | associated_acts = [[Bhoomi (band)|Bhoomi]] | website = [http://www.krosswindz.com www.krosswindz.com] }} '''Krosswindz''' ([[Bengali Language|Bengali]]: ক্রসউইন্ডস) is a Bengali rock/folk-fusion band, based in [[Kolkata]], [[India]]. They have played all over India and abroad, and have helped urbanize the folk music of Bengal and have tried to make it popular. Krosswindz is one of the few Kolkata based Bengali rock bands who have female singers in their lead vocals. {{Cite web|url=https://www.telegraphindia.com/1051029/asp/weekend/story_5394296.asp|title=The Telegraph - Calcutta : Weekend|website=www.telegraphindia.com|access-date=2018-02-25}}{{Cite news|url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/bengali/movies/news/kolkata-based-band-krosswindz-nominated-for-grassroot-grammys/articleshow/59662058.cms|title=Kolkata-based band Krosswindz nominated for Grassroot Grammys - Times of India|work=The Times of India|access-date=2018-02-25}} == History == The band was formed in 1990, and started out playing at college festivals. Today, they have toured all over India and have played at all major college festivals and stadium concerts. The band has performed and collaborated with internationally reputed names like Herbie Hancock (USA), Sky High ([[Sweden]]), Tizian Jost (Germany),Pandit Ramesh Mishra (Indian Sarangi Player) and The Jazz Ambassadors(USA).{{Citation needed|date=October 2012}} The band's music has been featured in numerous documentary films and commercials.{{Citation needed|date=October 2012}} == Members == * Vikramjit (Tuki) Banerjee - Lead guitars,vocals,songwriter,producer (also worked with [[Bhoomi (band)|Bhoomi]]) * Chandrani Banerjee - Lead vocals,Songwriter (also worked with Bhoomi) * Ratanjit - Keyboards, Indian folk instruments == Albums == {| class="wikitable" |- ! Ltd. |- | 1995 || ''[[Aabaar Bochhor Kuri Pore]]'' || Asha Audio |- | 1994 || ''Singles'' || BMG Crescendo (India) |} == See also == * [[Bhoomi (Music)|Bhoomi]] ==References== == Further reading == #{{cite news |title=Of music, energy and connection - revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{Advert|date=December 2014}} {{Tone|date=December 2014}} }} The Cultural Centre KULTURFABRIK is located at the heart of the Great Region in the south of the [[Grand Duchy of Luxembourg]], in [[Esch-sur-Alzette]] in the old buildings of a public slaughterhouse<ref>service des Sites et Monuments nationaux, {{cite web |url=http://www.ssmn.public.lu/patrimoine/industriel/conservation_mise_valeur/esch_alzette_ancien_abattoir/index.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-10-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131016004350/http://www.ssmn.public.lu/patrimoine/industriel/conservation_mise_valeur/esch_alzette_ancien_abattoir/index.html |archivedate=2013-10-16 |df= }}.</ref> from the 19th Century.[[File:Kufa by night.jpg|thumb|Kufa by night.]]
== History ==
*1885 / 86- 1979: public slaughterhouse house of Esch-sur-Alzette [[File:Vue abattoir.jpg|thumb|The old slaughterhouse of Esch-sur-Alzette.]] *From 1982: squat of artists from the non-profit « Theater GmbH », who turned the premises into a space for rehearsals and performances *1983: creation of the non-profit organisation KULTURFABRIK *1984–1995: all kinds of artistic and sociocultural activities *End of 1996: signing of an agreement between the State, the City of Esch-sur-Alzette and the Kulturfabrik *October 2, 1998: official opening of the Cultural Centre Kulturfabrik
Currently, the Cultural Centre is used as a center for the creative arts, artist residencies and as a platform for sustainable development [[File:L'extérieur de la Kultufabrik..jpg|thumb|The Kulturfabrik is an innovative platform for sustainable development]]<ref>''[[luxemburger Wort]]'', 3 octobre 2013, édition Saint-Paul Luxembourg, page 12.</ref>
== Equipments ==
A 4500 m2 area with *Big concert & theatre hall (950 standing/ 270 seated capacity) [[File:Out Of The Crowd.jpg|thumb|The big concert hall.]] *A small hall (250 standing) *The « Ratelach »: a small room for readings, conferences or other activities (up to 35 capacity) [[File:Ratelach.JPG|thumb|The « Ratelach »: a small room for readings, conferences or other activities .]] *An art gallery: «Galerie Terres Rouges» *Six rehearsal rooms for musicians [[File:Répétition Mutiny on the bounty.jpg|thumb|Mutiny On the Bounty at work.]] *Three rooms for theatre workshops, training and rehearsals *A ceramic atelier (Keramikfabrik) *the cinema (Kinosch) *the centre's restaurant (K116) (Tel: 26 17 59 74)
== Network and certifications ==
*Luxembourgish Network of Decentralized Cultural Centres *[[Trans Europe Halles]] *European Federation of Poetry Centres (Maisons de la poésie) *« Theaterfederatioun » *Circus Lorraine *Approved Centre for the National Youth Service *Centre for Apprenticeship, approved by the Luxembourgish Chamber of Commerce
== External links == * [http://www.kulturfabrik.lu/param/1/home-kulturfabrik.html Kulturfabrik website]
== Notes and references == {{reflist}}
{{coord|49|30|14|N|5|59|15|E|region:LU-L_type:landmark_source:kolossus-dewiki|display=title}}
[[Category:Buildings and structures in Esch-sur-Alzette]]

{{Infobox book | name =Les Soleils des indépendances | title_orig = | translator = | image = Les Soleils des indépendances.jpg | image_caption = | author = | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = [[Côte d'Ivoire]] | language = [[French language|French]] | series = | subject = | genre = Novel | publisher = Éditions de Seuil | pub_date = 1970 | english_pub_date = | media_type = | pages = | isbn = 2-02-001137-9 | oclc = | dewey = | congress = | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''''Les Soleils des indépendances''''' (''The Suns of Independence'') is the [[first novel]] by [[Côte d'Ivoire|Ivorian]] author [[Ahmadou Kourouma]]. It won the [[Grand prix littéraire d'Afrique noire]] in 1969.
The title is a play on words involving the meaning of the [[Maninka language|Maninka]] word "télé", which can mean "sun", but also "day", "era" or "period [of time]".
==Bibliography== *''Les Soleils des indépendances'', Presses de l'Université de Montréal, 1968 **''The Suns of Independence'', Translator Adrian Adams, Holmes & Meier, 1981, {{ISBN|978-0-8419-0747-8}}<ref>[http://dannyreviews.com/h/Suns_Independence.html Book review by Danny Yee]</ref>
==References== {{reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Soleils Des Independances}} [[Category:Ivorian novels]] [[Category:1968 novels]] [[Category:French-language novels]] [[Category:Grand prix littéraire d'Afrique noire winners]] [[Category:Debut novels]]

{{Multiple issues| {{notability|Events|date=January 2017}} {{unreferenced|date=January 2017}} {{Orphan|date=February 2017}} }} {{Infobox music festival | image = [[File:12 Magnetic Festival Prague.jpg|260px]] | music_festival_name = MAGNETIC festival | location = [[PVA EXPO PRAHA]]
[[Prague]], [[Czech Republic]] | years_active = 2012-present | dates = twice a year - May and December | organiser = [[John Culter]] [[LIVE61 s.r.o.]] | genre =[[Electronic dance music]] | website = {{Official website|http://www.magneticfestival.com/ }} }} {{Coord|50.128438|14.514713|display=title}} '''MAGNETIC festival''' is an electronic music festival; established in 2012, the event is held biannually in Prague, the Czech Republic, on the premises of the PVA Expo trade fair halls. MAGNETIC Festival takes place in early May and mid-December. == History == The festival is the brainchild of John Culter, a DJ and a music producer. The very first MAGNETIC Festival took place on May 5, 2012, launching a series of recognized electronic music events within Central Europe. Since 2014, supporting events MAGNETIC Club Life and MAGNETIC Arena have become a part of the festival. == Editions == {| class="wikitable" !Year !Date !Headliners |- |2017 |15 December 2017 || * [[Don Diablo|DON DIABLO]] * MOKSI * LNY TNZ * [[Breathe Carolina|BREATHE CAROLINA]] * BROOKS * [[Chocolate Puma|CHOCOLATE PUMA]] * VINAI * [[Quintino (DJ)|QUINTINO]] * JOHN CULTER |- |2017 |5 May 2017 ||[[KURA|Kura]] [[Jewelz & Sparks]] [[NERVO (duo)|Nervo]] [[John Culter]] [[Kryder]] [[KURA]] [[Mesto]] [[Tom Swoon]] |- |2016 |16 December 2016 |[[R3hab]] [[Yellow Claw (DJs)|Yellow Claw]] [[Chocolate Puma]] [[Florian Picasso]] [[Jay Hardway]] John Culter [[Merk & Kremont]] [[Moksi]] [[TJR (DJ)|TJR]] |- |2016 |7 May 2016 |[[W&W]] [[The Chainsmokers]] [[Curbi]] [[D.O.D. (DJ)|D.O.D.]] [[Dannic]] [[Dyro]] John Culter [[Matisse & Sadko]] |- |2015 |18 December 2015 |[[Borgeous]] [[Laidback Luke]] [[Tujamo]] [[VINAI]] [[DubVision]] [[Joe Stone]] John Culter [[KURA]] [[Wiwek]] |- |2015 |7 May 2015 |[[Nicky Romero]] [[DVBBS]] John Culter [[Mike Hawkins (musician)|Mike Hawkins]] [[MOTi]] [[New World Sound]] [[Sick Individuals]] [[Stadiumx]] |- |2014 |19 December 2014 |[[Bassjackers]] [[Fedde Le Grand]] [[Firebeatz]] [[Jay Hardway]] [[Joey Dale]] John Culter [[Kill the Buzz]] [[Quintino]] [[VINAI]] [[Zawdi MC]] |- |2014 |7 May 2014 |[[Martin Garrix]] DVBBS [[Blasterjaxx]] [[Ummet Ozcan]] [[Dannic]] [[MAKJ]] [[Deniz Koyu]] John Culter [[Billy the Kit]] |- |2013 |20 December 2013 |[[Afrojack]] [[Laidback Luke]] [[Quintino]] [[Dyro]] [[Yves V]] John Culter [[Billy the Kit]] |- |2013 |7 May 2013 |[[Steve Aoki]] [[Nervo (DJs)|Nervo]] [[Sander van Doorn]] [[Showtek]] [[Chuckie (DJ)|Chuckie]] [[Tommy Trash]] John Culter |- |2012 |14 December 2012 |[[Hardwell]] [[Dimitri Vegas & Like Mike]] [[Dada Life]] [[Bingo Players]] John Culter [[Nari & Milani]] [[Hard Rock Sofa]] [[Swanky Tunes]] |- |2012 |7 May 2012 |[[Avicii]] [[Hardwell]] [[Dimitri Vegas & Like Mike]] Dada Life [[Laidback Luke]] [[Chuckie (DJ)|Chuckie]] [[Oliver Twizt]] [[David Tort]] |} ==External links== {{Commons}} * [https://festination.com/festivals/magnetic-festival/ Line up and important information] * [http://www.magneticfestival.com/ Official website] {{Portals|Music|Festivals}} [[Category:Music festivals established in 2012]] [[Category:Recurring events established in 2012]] [[Category:Electronic music festivals in the Czech Republic]] [[Category:2012 establishments in the Czech Republic]] [[Category:Spring (season) events in the Czech Republic]] [[Category:Winter events in the Czech Republic]] {{Czech-stub}}
