revision.text:
{{Infobox Airline | airline=Norlandair| logo=Norlandairlogo.PNG| logo_size = 150| fleet_size=4| destinations=3| IATA=<!--no iata-->| ICAO=FNA| callsign=NORLAND| founded=2008| headquarters=[[Akureyri]], [[Iceland]]| hubs=[[Akureyri Airport]]| key_people=Friðrik Adolfsson ([[Chief executive office|CEO]])| website= http://www.norlandair.is/| |image=|aoc=|focus_cities=|frequent_flyer=|parent=|num_employees=}}
'''Norlandair''' is an Icelandic airline. Norlandair was founded on 1 June 2008 when it acquired the [[De Havilland Canada DHC-6 Twin Otter|Twin Otter]] flight operation of [[Air Iceland]].
==History== The company can trace its roots to a company with the same name, i.e. Norlandair, which was founded in 1974. That company was founded by a few aviation professionals that acquired North Air, an aviation company based in [[Akureyri]]. ln 1975 [[Icelandair]] bought a stake in the company and by that Norlandair purchased a Twin Otter aircraft that was used in scheduled flights and charter flights. This event also marks the beginning of Norlandair offering aviation services on the east coast of [[Greenland]].
ln 1997, Norlandair and the domestic flight operations of Icelandair merged and the name was changed to Air Iceland. The charter flight department was located in Akureyri and the maintenance department for the Twin Otter aircraft. ln 2008 Air Iceland decided to divest the Twin Otter aircraft and the maintenance department in Akureyri. Following that decision, a few former employees of Air Iceland and investors decided to buy the operations from Air Iceland and it was decided to use the good name of Norlandair as the company was called prior to the merger with Icelandair.
== Destinations == Norlandair has three scheduled destinations, [[Grímsey Airport|Grímsey]], [[Vopnafjörður Airport|Vopnafjörður]] and [[Þórshöfn Airport|Þórshöfn]], which it flies in cooperation with Air Iceland. It also operates various charter flights in Iceland and [[Greenland]], to [[Svalbard]] and other arctic regions.
== Fleet == Norlandair's fleet consists of three [[de Havilland Canada DHC-6 Twin Otter]]s<ref>[http://loftfaraskra.caa.is/home/detail.php?id=627&lang=ISL Loftfaraskrá, Icelandic Civil Aviation Administration]</ref><ref>[http://loftfaraskra.caa.is/home/detail.php?id=570&lang=ISL Loftfaraskrá, Icelandic Civil Aviation Administration]</ref><ref>[http://loftfaraskra.caa.is/home/detail.php?id=1064&lang=ISL Loftfaraskrá, Icelandic Civil Aviation Administration]</ref> aircraft, including one it purchased from [[Air Greenland]] in 2011. Additionally it operates one [[Beechcraft Super King Air|Beechcraft B200 King Air]],<ref>[http://loftfaraskra.caa.is/home/detail.php?id=1053&lang=ISL Loftfaraskrá, Icelandic Civil Aviation Administration]</ref> and one [[GippsAero GA8 Airvan]].
<center> {| class="toccolours" border="1" cellpadding="3" style="border-collapse:collapse" |+ '''Norlandair fleet''' |-bgcolor=red !Aircraft !In Service !Passengers !Notes |- |[[de Havilland Canada DHC-6 Twin Otter|De Havilland Canada DHC-6-300 Twin Otter]] |<center>3<ref>{{cite journal|title=Global Airline Guide 2016 (Part One)|journal=Airliner World|issue=October 2016|page=16|accessdate=15 October 2016}}</ref> |<center>19 | |- |[[Beechcraft Super King Air|Beechcraft B200 King Air]] |<center>1 |<center>7 | |- !Total !4 ! ! |} </center>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== {{Commons category inline|Norlandair}} *[http://www.norlandair.is/ Official website]

revision.comment: ([[c:GR|GR]]) [[c:COM:FR|File renamed]]: [[File:Peacearchuscanadaborder.JPG]] → [[File:Peace Arch, U.S.-Canada border.jpg]] typo fixes
revision.text:
[[image:UStankParis-edit1.jpg|thumb|200px|Despite a long record of armed conflicts between Germany and France, the European security community has made war between these two less likely.]]
A '''security community''' is a [[region]] in which a large-scale use of [[violence]] (such as [[war]]) has become very unlikely or even unthinkable.<ref name='tusicisny'>{{cite journal|title=Security Communities and Their Values: Taking Masses Seriously|journal=International Political Science Review |date=2007 |first1=Andrej |last1=Tusicisny |volume=28|issue=4|pages=425–449|doi= 10.1177/0192512107079639 |url=http://www.tusicisny.com/research/tusicisny_security_communities_and_their_values.pdf|format=PDF|accessdate=2008-04-22 }}</ref> The term was coined by the prominent political scientist [[Karl Deutsch]] in 1957. In their seminal work ''Political Community and the North Atlantic Area: International Organization in the Light of Historical Experience'', Deutsch and his collaborators defined a security community as "a group of people" believing "that they have come to agreement on at least this one point: that common social problems must and can be resolved by processes of 'peaceful change{{'"}}.<ref name='deutsch'>{{cite book | last1 = Deutsch | first1 = Karl W. | authorlink = | title = Political Community and the North Atlantic Area: International Organization in the Light of Historical Experience | publisher = Princeton University Press | date = 1957 | location = Princeton|display-authors=etal}}</ref> Peaceful change was defined as "the resolution of social problems, normally by institutionalized procedures, without resort to large-scale physical force".<ref name='deutsch'/> People in a security community are also bound by the "sense of [[community]]", the mutual sympathy, trust, and common interests.<ref name='deutsch'/>
The concept has not become a [[mainstream]] term in the field of [[international security]] despite its long history. After the end of the [[Cold War]], the concept of a security community was adapted by [[Constructivism in international relations|constructivist]] scholars. A major impetus was the book ''Security Communities'' (1998), edited by [[Emanuel Adler]] and [[Michael N. Barnett|Michael Barnett]]. They redefined the security community by shared identities, [[Value (personal and cultural)|values]], and meanings; many-sided direct interactions; and reciprocal long-term interest.<ref name='ab'>{{cite book | last1= Adler | first1=Emanuel |author2=Michael Barnett | title = Security Communities | publisher = Cambridge University Press | date = 1998 | location = Cambridge | pages = | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = }}</ref> Several regions of the world have been studied in the security community framework since then, most notably the European Union, the Canada–United States and Mexico–United States [[:wikt:dyad|dyads]], [[Mercosur]], and [[Association of South East Asian Nations]] (ASEAN).<ref name='tusicisny'/> [[Michael Haas (political scientist)|Michael Haas]] compared the [[Asian and Pacific Council]], [[Asian-Pacific Parliamentarians Union]], ASEAN, [[Indochinese Foreign Ministers Conference]], [[South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation]], [[Southeast Asia Treaty Organization]], and the South Pacific Forum (later renamed the [[Pacific Islands Forum]]).
==Types of security communities==
Deutsch divided security communities into two types: the amalgamated and pluralistic ones.<ref name='deutsch'/> Amalgamated security communities are quite rare in history. They are created when two or more previously independent [[sovereign state|state]]s form a common government. An example is the United States after the original [[thirteen colonies]] ceded much of their governing powers to the [[federation|federal]] government. Amalgamation is not always successful and can be overturned, as the failed [[Union between Sweden and Norway]] exemplifies.<ref name='deutsch'/> An alternative and less ambitious process is called [[regional integration|integration]]. Integration leads to a pluralistic security community, in which states retain their sovereignty.<ref name='deutsch'/> The United States with Canada is an example of a pluralistic security community.<ref name='tusicisny'/> Both countries are politically independent, but they do not expect to have future military confrontations, in spite of [[War of 1812|having had some]] in the past. Deutsch argued that the pluralistic security communities are easier to establish and maintain than their amalgamated counterparts.<ref name='deutsch'/>
Adler and Barnett described the typical evolution of a security community from nascent to ascendant to mature. A nascent security community meets the basic expectations of peaceful change, while a mature security community is also characterized by some [[collective security]] mechanisms and [[supranationalism|supranational]] or [[transnationalism|transnational]] elements.<ref name='ab'/> Adler and Barnett further divided the mature security communities into "tightly" and "loosely coupled", depending on the level of their integration.<ref name='ab'/>
Raimo Väyrynen<ref name='vayrynen'>{{Cite journal |first=Raimo |last=Väyrynen |contribution=Stable Peace Through Security Communities? Steps Towards Theory-Building |title=Occasional Paper # 18:OP:3 |publisher=The Joan B. Kroc Institute For International Peace Studies| place=| pages=| date=2000| year=| id= | contribution-url=http://kroc.nd.edu/ocpapers/op_18_3.pdf| format=PDF| postscript=<!--None--> }}</ref> and Andrej Tusicisny<ref name='tusicisny'/> differentiated between interstate security communities (where war between states is unlikely) and comprehensive security communities (where both interstate conflicts and [[civil wars]] are seen as unthinkable). [[Western Europe]] is a classic example of a comprehensive security community, while [[South East Asia]] is usually seen as an interstate security community.<ref name='tusicisny'/><ref name='vayrynen'/>
==Conditions leading to a security community==
[[image:Peace Arch, U.S.-Canada border.jpg|thumb|200px|The demilitarized border between Canada and the United States, two members of the North American security community.]]
According to Deutsch, states may form a security community if the current state of the international system increases "unattractiveness and improbability of war among the political units concerned".<ref name='deutsch'/> For instance, security concerns led the United States and Mexico to form a pluralistic security community in anticipation of [[World War II]].<ref name='gh'>{{Cite book| first1=Guadalupe | last1=Gonzalez|author2=Stephan Haggard| contribution=The United States and Mexico: A Pluralistic Security Community| title=Security Communities| editor-first=Emanuel| editor-last=Adler| publisher=Cambridge University Press| place=Cambridge |year=1998 <!--|accessdate=2008-04-22-->|editor2=Michael Barnett| postscript=<!--None--> }}</ref> Deutsch identified two conditions that should facilitate formation of a pluralistic security community. The first one is "the capacity of the participating political units or governments to respond to each other's needs, messages, and actions quickly, adequately, and without resort to violence".<ref name='deutsch'/> One way states build this capacity is by common membership in [[international organization]]s.<ref name='ab'/> The second condition is the "compatibility of major values relevant to political decision-making".<ref name='deutsch'/> An example of a major politically relevant value given by Deutsch is political [[ideology]].<ref name='deutsch'/> However, more recent empirical research showed that the often hypothesized role of [[liberalism|liberal]] values and general [[Trust (social sciences)|trust]] in the development of security communities is overestimated.<ref name='tusicisny'/> Another test, by Michael Haas, compared successful with unsuccessful security-community-oriented organizations, finding that the principal variable with a statistically significant relationship out of Deutsch's 12 variables was mutual compatibility of main values.<ref name='Haas'>{{cite article| last = Haas | first = Michael | authorlink = | title = Comparing Regional Cooperation in Asia and the Pacific," In Toward a World of Peace, eds. Jeannette P. Mass and Robert A. C. Stewart | publisher= University of the South Pacific Press | date = 1986 | location = Suva, Fiji | pages = 149–168 | isbn = 982-01-0003-8}}</ref>
Since amalgamation is more demanding than integration, Deutsch identified eight conditions that should be satisfied if amalgamation is to succeed: the mutual compatibility of main values, a distinctive way of life, capabilities and processes of cross-cutting [[communication]], high [[Population mobility|geographic]] and [[social mobility|social]] mobility, multiplicity and balance of transactions, a significant frequency of some interchange in group roles, a broadening of the political [[elite]], and high political and administrative capabilities.<ref name='deutsch'/> In addition, the politically relevant [[Social stratification|strata]] of the population should be willing to accept and support common governmental institutions, remain loyal to them, and operate these common institutions with mutual attention to the messages and needs of all participating units.<ref name='deutsch'/>
Carol Weaver has posited that, in order to arise and endure, security communities need to be based on balanced multipolarity.<ref>Weaver, C.[http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/09662839.2010.510517 "Black Sea Regional Security: present multipolarity and future possibilities"], ''European Security'',Vol. 20 (1), 2011, pp. 1-19.</ref><ref>Weaver, C.[http://www.ashgate.com/isbn/9781409463665 "The Politics of the Black Sea Region: EU neighbourhood, conflict zone or future security community?"], ''Ashgate Publishing'',2013.</ref>
==Other uses==
The term ''security community'' may also refer to a policy community working on issues of [[security]]. It can be a [[hierarchy|hierarchical]] or [[social network|networked]] group of professionals consisting, for instance, of politicians, military and civilian bureaucrats, and researchers. An example is the computer security community working on [[computer security]].
==References== {{reflist}}

revision.text: {{Distinguish|Sex and Love Addicts Anonymous|Sexaholics Anonymous|Sexual Recovery Anonymous|Sexual Compulsives Anonymous}} '''Sex Addicts Anonymous''' ('''SAA''') is a [[twelve-step program]] for people who want to stop their addictive sexual behavior.{{cite web |url=http://saa-recovery.org/OurProgram/TheTwelveTraditions/ |title=The Twelve Traditions |author=Sex Addicts Anonymous |accessdate=16 March 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5xEQzDTum?url=http://saa-recovery.org/OurProgram/TheTwelveTraditions/ |archivedate=16 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} There also exists a group known as '''COSA''', for those who have been impacted by others' sexual addiction.{{cite web |url=http://www.cosa-recovery.org/home.html |title=Welcome to COSA |accessdate=2007-12-23 |author=COSA |date=2007-12-08}} ==Introduction== SAA was founded in 1977 by several men who wanted a greater sense of anonymity than what they perceived in other twelve step programs for sex addicts. SAA is open to anyone who desires greater control over their behavior, and is intended to be safe for people of all [[sexual orientation]]s.{{cite book |last=Parker |first=Jan |author2=Guest, Diana |editor=Adams, Kenneth |editor2=Carnes, Patrick J. |chapter=Chapter 8: Integration of Psychotherapy and 12-Step Programs |pages=115–124 |title=Clinical Management of Sex Addiction |year=2002 |publisher=Psychology Press |isbn=1-58391-361-0 |oclc=49312705 |location=[[New York City|New York]]}} In SAA each member creates a unique definition of "sexual sobriety" based on abstaining from a personalized list of compulsive sexual behaviors. Members are encouraged to respect each other's definitions of sobriety. Many SAA members use a "three circle" concept to model their behaviors. The inner circle represents the compulsive sexual behaviors that must not be practiced. Inner circle behaviors might include having sex with a [[prostitute]], or [[acting out]] with a nonconsensual victim. The outer circle includes sexual and nonsexual behaviors that are definitely healthy. Outer circle behaviors might include sex with a partner in a [[monogamy|monogamous relationship]] or getting eight hours of sleep a night. In the middle circle are behaviors that are not considered a [[relapse]] (inner circle behaviors), but could quickly lead to one if left unchecked. Middle circle behaviors might include looking for a prostitute or contacting an old [[acting out]] partner. In addition to regular meetings SAA also organizes "boundary meetings." These are special meetings for professional caregivers such as medical doctors, psychotherapists, and clergy who need to attend meetings separate from clients, patients, and parishioners.{{cite journal |last=Birchard |first=Thaddeus |title='The snake and the seraph' - sexual addiction and religious behavior |journal=Counselling Psychology Quarterly |year=2004 |volume=17 |issue=1 |pages=81–88 |doi=10.1080/09515070410001665703 |oclc=18582175}} Some SAA members (a minority) may have a history of [[sexual abuse]] during their childhood, and more [[substance abuse]] problems than [[Scientific control|control groups]].{{cite book |last=Hunter |first=Mic |title=Abused Boys: The Neglected Victims of Sexual Abuse |chapter=Chapter 4: Life Areas Affected by Childhood Sexual Abuse |publisher=Lexington Books |location=Lexington, MA |year=1990 |isbn=0-669-20866-3 |oclc=246877991 |pages=59–92}}{{cite journal |last1=Plant |first1=Moira |last2=Miller |first2=Patrick |last3=Plant |first3=Marting |title=Childhood and Adult Sexual Abuse: Relationships with Alcohol and other Psychoactive Drug Use |journal=Child Abuse Review |volume=13 |issue=3 |pages=200–214 |year=2004 |doi=10.1002/car.845}} SAA publishes the book ''Sex Addicts Anonymous''. It is widely used in SAA and has been officially approved as their basic text by the ISO of SAA, Inc Literature Committee. It has gained the approval of the annual conference of group delegates.{{cite book |author=Sex Addicts Anonymous |title=Sex Addicts Anonymous |publisher=International Service Organization of SAA |year=2005 |isbn=0-9768313-1-7 |oclc=247995491}} ==Meetings== Several types of meetings are offered at SAA: in-person meetings, telemeetings, and online meetings. Meetings can be mixed (meaning both men and women attend) or gender-specific (men-only meetings vs. women-only meetings). Meetings that are advertised as closed are “open only to those individuals who have a desire to stop their addictive behavior"; in contrast, open meetings are “open to anyone interested in…SAA,” regardless of whether the individual has expressed a desire to change.[http://saa-recovery.org/Meetings/ SAA — Meetings] Additionally, telemeetings, or meetings via conference calls, and internet-based meetings are sources of real-time support outside of the traditional in-person meeting. In the United States, SAA meetings are held in all fifty states as well as the District of Columbia and Puerto Rico.[http://saa-recovery.org/Meetings/UnitedStates/ SAA — Meetings | United States] ==Sponsors== A sponsor is a member that has been part of the program for a large period of time and has attained a desirable level of [[sex]] sobriety. These individuals will help new members by offering a more personal level of availability in order to answer questions when needed. Usually, newcomers will find a proper sponsor after attending a few meetings taking in consideration the level of comfort between the new member and the old one, but if a good relationship is attained, the new attendee will continue to be guided by this person.[http://saa-recovery.org/OurProgram/Sponsorship/ SAA — Our Program | Sponsorship] ==COSA== COSA is a recovery program for family or friends whose lives have been affected by someone else's compulsive sexual behavior. The official name of the organization is the [[Acronym and initialism|acronym]] COSA; it is no longer the [[abbreviation]] C.O.S.A. as there was no agreement that it stood for either 'Codependents of Sex Addicts' or 'Co-Sex Addicts'. Each COSA member may choose to define him/herself as a codependent of sexual addiction, as a co-sex addict, or simply as a member of COSA, according to his or her own personal experience and conscience.[http://www.cosa-recovery.org/acronym.html About the COSA Acronym, Steps, and Traditions]. COSA. Retrieved 2010-10-21. == See also == * [[List of twelve-step groups]] * [[Sexaholics Anonymous]] * [[Sexual addiction]] * [[Sex and Love Addicts Anonymous]] * [[Sexual Compulsives Anonymous]] == References == {{reflist|2}} == External links == * [http://saa-recovery.org/ Sex Addicts Anonymous] * [http://www.cosa-recovery.org/ COSA] * {{worldcat id|id=lccn-n2006-81653}} [[Category:Human sexuality organizations]] [[Category:Twelve-step programs]] [[Category:Non-profit organizations based in Texas]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1977]] [[Category:International medical and health organizations‎]] [[Category:Sexual addiction]] [[Category:LGBT family and peer support groups]]

[[Mikael Aemiro Awake]] | starring = Rasselas Lakew | music = | cinematography = | editing = Davey Frankel | distributor = | released = {{Film date|df=y|2009|6||[[Edinburgh International Film Festival|EIFF]]}} | runtime = 93 minutes | country = Ethiopia | language = Amharic, English, Oromo, Norwegian | budget = }} '''''The Athlete''''' ({{lang-am|እትሌቱ}}, ''Atletu'') is a 2009 Ethiopian [[drama film]] directed by [[Davey Frankel]] and [[Rasselas Lakew]]. The film was selected as the Ethiopian entry for the [[Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film|Best Foreign Language Film]] at the [[83rd Academy Awards]],{{cite web |url=http://www.oscars.org/members/screenings/scr_flfa/white.html |title=2010-2011 Foreign Language Film Award Screening Schedule |accessdate=24 December 2010|work=Oscars.org}} but it did not make the final shortlist.{{cite web |url=http://www.oscars.org/press/pressreleases/2011/20110119.html |title=9 Foreign Language Films Continue to Oscar Race |accessdate=19 January 2011|work=oscars.org}} It was the first Ethiopian film to be submitted in the category for Best Foreign Language Film.{{cite web |url=http://www.oscars.org/press/pressreleases/2010/20101013a.html |title=65 Countries Enter Race for 2010 Foreign Language Film Oscar |accessdate=24 December 2010|work=Oscars.org}} The film has been reviewed in an international journal.Aboneh Ashagrie. 2013. The Athlete: a movie about the Ethiopian barefooted Olympic champion. ''Journal of African Cultural Studies'' Vol. 25, No. 1, 119–121. A mixture of fiction and stock footage, ''The Athlete'' is a portrait of the marathon runner from Ethiopia, [[Abebe Bikila]]. In 1960, he participated in the [[1960 Summer Olympics|Rome Olympic Games]] as a complete unknown. However, the son of a shepherd ran barefoot and won the gold medal. Four years later, he repeated his feat at the Tokyo Olympic Games, becoming the first man to win the Olympic marathon twice in a row. A few years later, he suffered a car accident and lost the use of his legs. He died four years later. ==Cast== * [[Rasselas Lakew]] as [[Abebe Bikila]] * [[Dag Malmberg]] as Onni * [[Ruta Gedmintas]] as Charlotte * [[Abba Waka Dessalegn]] as The Priest ==See also== * [[List of submissions to the 83rd Academy Awards for Best Foreign Language Film]] * [[List of Ethiopian submissions for the Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film]] * [[Athletics at the 1960 Summer Olympics – Men's marathon]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|1130965|Atletu}} * {{Official website|1=http://www.theathlete-film.com/The_Athlete/The_Athlete.html}} * {{RefFCAT|410}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Athlete}} [[Category:2009 films]] [[Category:2000s drama films]] [[Category:Amharic-language films]] [[Category:Ethiopian films]] [[Category:Running films]] [[Category:Films about the 1960 Summer Olympics]] [[Category:Films about the 1964 Summer Olympics]] [[Category:Films about Olympic track and field]] [[Category:Films shot in Bulgaria]] [[Category:Films shot in Norway]] [[Category:Films set in 1969]] [[Category:Films set in Ethiopia]] [[Category:Biographical films about sportspeople]] {{Ethiopia-film-stub}}

Belyakova | distributor = | released = {{film date|2001|5|18|df=yes}} | runtime = 85 minutes | country = Kazakhstan | language = Kazakh | budget = }} '''''The Road''''' ({{lang-kk|Jol}}) is a 2001 [[list of Kazakhstani films|Kazakhstani]] [[drama film]] directed by [[Darezhan Omirbaev]]. It was screened in the [[Un Certain Regard]] section at the [[2001 Cannes Film Festival]].{{cite web |url=http://www.festival-cannes.com/en/archives/ficheFilm/id/1100044/year/2001.html |title=Festival de Cannes: The Road |accessdate=2009-10-21|work=festival-cannes.com}} ==Cast== * [[Jamshed Usmonov]] - Amir Kobessov * [[Saule Toktybayeva]] - Amir's mother * [[Alnur Turgambayeva]] - Amir's wife * [[Magjane Omirbayev]] - Amir's son / Amir as a child * [[Valeria Gouliaeva]] - Veronika, the waitress * [[Valeri Skoribov]] - Censorship agent * [[Moukhamedjane Alpisbaev]] - Amir's school friend * [[Serik Aprimov]] - The avenging brother ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{imdb title|id=0301481|title=The Road}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Road, The}} [[Category:2001 films]] [[Category:Kazakhstani films]] [[Category:Kazakh-language films]] [[Category:2000s drama films]] [[Category:Films directed by Darezhan Omirbaev]] {{Kazakhstan-film-stub}}
